A reminder, there are only a few days left to post entries to the April Contest (STORM) which closes at midnight on the 30th.

(see upcoming themes below)

NOTE: The meetup on MAY 21: Farm Implement Junkyard & Steam Show  will provide lots of junk to photograph.  You may enter images from anywhere, but if you are attending the meetup, you will have photos from there to post.

Special instructions will appear on the contest album's cover image or its comments when the contest opens.

The photo album will open at 3:15 a.m. on the 1st of the month. Photos submitted after midnight on the last day of the month will not be eligible. If you post a photo and change your mind, you may delete it and replace it with a different photo before the deadline. If more than 2 photos are submitted, the first 2 will be judged; the 3rd will not.

Please check contest rules if you have not already done so: http://www.meetup.com/pittsburgh-photo-safari/messages/boards/thread/32726552 

________

I may add suggestions for some topics. You are free to use them or not. However, if something is marked with SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS, those must be followed.

June 2016: Fabric or Textile 

July 2016: Patriotic

August 2016: Garden

September 2016: Work

October 2016: Paper

November 2016: Music

December 2016: Vivid Colors  It is highly suggested that you submit entries with naturally-occurring vivid colors rather than manipulating them with extreme saturation.

About Italiano-Espresso©:

Italiano-Espresso was created with the idea of having weekly conversation get-togethers for all Italophiles to meet, practice and/or learn something Italian or in Italian.

Each week, there is one suggested/scheduled activity that will engage all speakers (from beginners to advanced and natives) in a fun and welcoming atmophere.

Spontaneous conversation is also welcome.

For those looking for a more structured learning environment, come and join us on Tuesdays (beginners) or Thursdays (intermediate) for Italian class (6:45pm/Wilkins School Community Center).

Italiano-Espresso is mainly held in coffeshops (i.e. the name "Italiano Espresso) and the location is chosen by the attendees on a monthly bases.

So, com'on out if you'd like to see us bring ITALIANO-ESPRESSO in your neck of the woods.

BIG NEWS: we have a BLOG!


The blog of Italiano Espresso is now online!

Wanna know more about our meetings? Check here the funniest topics we mention every Sunday: http://mondoitaliano.tumblr.com/

results.description:
Beekeeping Club Organizer Joe Zgurzynski will host a training session for beekeepers interested in hosting apiary tours for club members.  The goal is for beekeepers to become more comfortable teaching other beekeepers.  The discussion will cover what should be worn, topics to mention and basic apiary safety.  We will open a bee hive as part of the training if the weather permits.

This apiary training is best suited for current beekeepers with at least one year of experiance.  There is a chance that you could be stung while visit the hives.  Veils must be worn.  If you need to purchase a veil you can get one from Country Barn Farm by contacting <a>[masked]</a>.  We will inspecting hives if the weather permits.  Please wear or bring a long sleeve shirt, long pants and closed toed shoes or boots.  If you need to use gloves, plan to wear new / disposable gloves to reduce the risk of disease transmission between apiaries.  Joe Zgurzynski will have disposable gloves available.


You will be asked to sign a release of liability form.  Please follow this link: Release Form 

Please print our the form and bring a signed copy with you for you apiary tour host.
results.name: Hive Inspection Training for Apiary Tour Hosts

THE BLOCK PARTY! SPRING HILL!


Sunday May 1st
4pm-7pm
2000 Rockledge St. Pittsburgh, Pa

Featuring Bands:
DELICIOUS PASTRIES
BREWER’S ROW
THE GET DOWN GANG

The Block Party, a project of One Northside in partnership with The Buhl Foundation, is a series of mini arts festivals that will call attention to and celebrate the valuable resources and local identities of the eighteen Northside neighborhoods of Pittsburgh

Located north of Downtown and neighboring Spring Garden and Troy Hill, Spring Hill is a picturesque neighborhood named for its hilly topography and natural underground springs. This “bedroom community nestled on the hilltop” sprang from German ethnic roots many decades ago and today houses neighbors of diverse races, economics, and social status that gives the community a melting-pot flavor.
This event is taking place in the new Asylgärten Park, a large lot owned for many years by the Spring Hill Civic League that is currenty undergoing a renovation as a welcoming community space.

• Food trucks will be onsite
• Stories about the neighborhood are being collected onsite by The Saturday Light Brigade.
• Hands-on activities with Pittsburgh Center for Creative Reuse and Little House Big Art.
• Public art with AIR: Artists Image Resource
• Refreshments featuring the local, in-progress brewery, Spring Hill Brewing.
• Activities with Mattress Factory – Museum of Contemporary Art.
• Historical photos courtesy of Allegheny City Historic Gallery.
results.name: The Block Party - #1 Spring Hill

results.description:
This is the album to use if you want your shots to be critiqued. Please don't upload to this album unless you are prepared for feedback. 

All photos posted to this album are open to constructive criticism. You do not have to add a caption or comment to say that your photo is open to criticism.

OTR: "Open for Retouching" -  If you add OTR to a caption or comment, you are agreeing that it's okay for someone to download your photograph and retouch it. Retouching will only take place if you label it as OTR.  Otherwise no one is to assume you want your photo retouched.  

NEVER download and retouch a photo without OTR (or Open to Retouching) being in the comments. It you retouch a photo without permission and put it back on the site, that retouched photo will be immediately removed.


* For the Critiquers...please be polite when you post critiques. As with all opinions they can be taken harshly when not intended that way. Make sure you re-read your comments before you post them and make sure they are as clear as possible. 

Remember to write constructive criticisms.  Tell the photographer how an image could have been improved when taking the photo and/or how to enhance it to improve it.  Your critique should not be a long list of negative qualities, but rather, a few suggestions for improvement.


Although  the official event time is 7:00 pm, the album will not open until 10 pm.
results.name: Monthly Critiques - May 2016

Guidelines for the meet up:


1) Be on time, when you come in late (after 7:55AM) then you cause a disruption for everyone who got there on time.  Parents get a pass if they had to send someone off to school but otherwise please make best efforts to be early (help set up), get coffee, use the restroom, etc before we start.

In Level II students are given complete tools for working with Reiki energy both in person and through “absentee” techniques. Level II Reiki amplifies the Reiki I energy and produces a grounding or solidifying of the energy as it settles into the student’s aura in a profound manner. In Reiki Level II, students are given ancient Sanskrit symbols which allow the Reiki energy to perform powerful functions, such as specific mental/emotional/spiritual healing and long distance healing.

• Ancient Sanskrit symbols: their names, meanings, and uses

results.description:
New Project!

The Landmarks That Departed Map will bring a longstanding Pittsburgh tradition into the digital age.

Like many helpful humans in the city, it will provide navigation directions using only landmarks that are no longer in existence.

Many props must go to Stuff That's Gone and Things That Aren't There Anymore, two Rick Sebak documentaries about this very topic.

There are a few things that this will require:
* a system for describing the key attributes of now-gone buildings and structures (location, street address, time of destruction, etc)
* the data about such sites in South Western PA
* and a website by which those locations can be strung together into routes and the directions implied by those routes.

During this meeting, we will dive into two pieces of this work: defining key attributes of the data (creating a data standard), and creating a list of potential data resources.

Future meetings will delve into the visualization mechanism.

Community organizations with an interest in historical mapping are encouraged to send representatives.

If you can't attend the meeting, definitely comment on the project plan, located here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1hQrrDb3amkpYZScT8Cg3UdJg1wzQOCWR2H4X5OYUrR4/edit
results.name: Landmarks That Departed Map - Kickoff Meeting

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."

Come and play ukulele with us at the Unitarian Universalist Church of the North Hills on the first and third Mondays of each month. All levels of play are welcome, and we are novice-friendly. Some people who come have never even held a ukulele, and if you contact Sandy ahead of time, she will bring an extra ukulele for you to try. Try Ukulele.... It's Really Fun!

Music is usually selected from "The Daily Ukulele... 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is readily available at music stores, book stores, and Amazon.com.  Sometimes members bring other music to play (bring 15 copies to share). We play seated at a large conference table. Bring a table-top music stand if you have one.

Snacks and libations to share are welcome.

For more information, contact Sandy at [masked]

Directions to the Church: Take I279 North to Wexford exit. Turn right at the end of the exit. Right at the light onto Brandt School Road. Right onto West Ingomar Road to 2359. Note: Watch for the large Church sign and turn right, then you will follow a narrow road back through the trees to the Church. We meet in a room just inside the door. If you are driving North from Pittsburgh on I-279, take Exit 8 Camp Horne Road, Go north and then take Rochester Road. West Ingomar Road is just past the Franklin Inn (turn right and then a quick left, and the Church driveway is in sight on your left.

Look for this sign. Note: it is lit at night

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Monday night tennis for all levels - Cranberry

results.description:
If you've never explored the Morton Valley Trail in Boyce-Mayview Park, you'll be in for a treat!  It's beautiful to walk through and has been rated one of the best walking trails in the city!   We will walk at a slow to moderate pace for about an hour.  Wear waterproof hiking shoes/ boots and dress accordingly to walking on trails that may be a bit muddy.  Bring a water bottle and snack if you'd like.  

Directions from US Rt. 19 (Washington Road)


Proceed south on US Rt. 19 (Washington Road) to Boyce Road which is 3.0 miles south of South Hills Village Shopping Center (at Ft. Couch Road). Turn right onto Boyce Road and proceed 0.5 miles to the intersection with Morton Road on the right. Turn right and then immediately left into the garden plot parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

If the gate to the garden plots is closed or as an alternate, continue on Boyce Road another 0.6 miles to the paved turn-off just before Ardolino's Pizza on the right 

Another alternate entrance is on Mayview Road. Continue on Boyce Road to the intersection with Mayview Road (next traffic light) and turn right. Proceed 1.1 miles on Mayview Road to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

Directions from Interstate 79

Take Bridgeville exit (No. 54) from I-79. At the end of the exit ramp, turn right onto Millers Run Road (PA Route 50) and proceed to the traffic light at the T-instersection with Washington Pike in front of the Exxon station. Turn right onto Washington Pike and drive for for 2.1 miles to the intersection with Boyce Road. Turn right onto Boyce and proceed 1.4 miles to the traffic light at the intersection with Mayview Road.

If you want to enter the park through the wetlands, turn left on to Mayview road and drive for 1.1 miles to the railroad track crossing (indicated by “C” on the map). Park in the small triangle of land on the west side of Mayview Road bordered by the railroad tracks and Chartiers Creek. (There is room for only 2 or 3 cars.) Cross Mayview Road and enter the park through the gate to the wetlands.

To use the Boyce Road entrances to the park, continue on Boyce Road for another 0.5 mile to Ardolino's Pizza on the left. There is a paved turn off and parking area just past the pizza shop.

You can also use the garden plot parking area at the intersection with Morton Road. Proceed another 0.6 mile to the intersection with Morton Road on the left. Turn left and then another immediate left into the parking area (indicated by “A” on the map).

results.description:
There is much, Much, MUCH more to Louis Armstrong than you could ever imagine. Whatever your generation, you might associate him with "It's a Wonderful World," or "Hello Dolly," or "Cabaret." These were hits from the last decade of his life, but did you realize that Louis Daniel Armstrong singlehandedly changed EVERYTHING about music? The way we sing, the way we phrase; in fact, he created swing.

During the 1920s Armstrong created the very essence of solo-oriented jazz performance through his sheer power and brilliance. And not just jazz! Classical musicians were deeply affected by his sound. We can't hear ANY piece of music anymore without hearing traces of his genius. Come and find out how this "illegitimate" child from the poorest and most dangerous neighborhood in the Deep South rose above poverty and prejudice to become an American Goodwill Ambassador.

Tom Roberts is one of the leading exponent of early jazz piano in the world today. Having played in all the major jazz clubs in the French Quarter and on the riverboats of New Orleans, Tom has also performed twice at New York's Carnegie Hall. Besides his piano artistry, Tom is a versatile music historian with special focus on the early jazz era. This is a 2-part series on May 3 and May 10.

FREE. Everyone is welcome!

For more information about the Mt. Lebanon Public Library, please visit http://mtlebanonlibrary.org/
results.name: Tom Roberts on Louis Armstrong

results.description:
We will gather at 5PM, and I will introduce you to the tiles, the card, and the game.  After the intro we usually have time for one or two games. Please try to arrive on time for this class!


You will not need your own 2016 Mah Jong card tonight, but you will need to buy one if you plan on playing after tonight.  You do not need to buy a Mah Jong set - we have plenty of sets.


We can eat while I'm going through the basics, so feel free to grab some food when you arrive at Panera.

I request a $10 fee for the beginner class -- payable at the beginning of the class.  If that is a problem for you, just let me know.  There is no charge for the weekly meetups ... only the classes.


Any questions?  You can reach me through the meetup group, or email me through the Pittsburgh Mah Jong web site:  http://pittsburghmahjong.com/contact/
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Mah Jong tiles on the table!
results.name: Mah Jong 101 - intro for beginners

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!
results.name: Mah Jong in Shadyside! (Note: beginner class also tonight!)

results.description:
Last month we had about 30 people attend, and had a lively discussion about how the changes in US-Cuba relations are impacting 'ordinary' working people, and Cuba's commitment to build worker controlled co-ops wherever possible in preference to privatization. Also, laws in place to protect Cuban workers from exploitation when they work in foreign 'joint ventures.'

This month, May, we will have a discussion led by Marisol Valentin, who has worked for Global Links for six years and is intimate with Cuba's healthcare system,  about healthcare as a fundamental human right, and how the Cuban's have created a system that now has the Cuban people experiencing a 10 year longer life span than we have in  the US (where our overall life expectancy is going down) lower maternal & infant mortality, preventive medicine, etc. 

Cuba has a world class and internationally respected healthcare system!

We will also be forming committees to explore the interests that our membership has expressed an interest in. 

General Meeting starts at 6:00 PM, Committee meetings from 6:30 - 7: 00 PM group discussion from 7:00 - 8:00 PM. Light refreshments served.

US policy on Cuba is changing very rapidly, so we hope you will join our meetup so that we can be the place where all your curiosity about Cuba can be nurtured!
results.how_to_find_us: Please call if you need directions: 412-303-1247 (Old Connally Schoolhouse)
results.name: CUBA-PITTSBURGH-CUBA Monthly Meeting!

results.description:
Price - FREE

Sarah will discuss the physical, emotional, and energetic qualities associated with the 5 seasonal elements: Fire-summer, Earth-late summer, Metal-autumn, Water-winter, and Wood-spring, in their balance and imbalanced states. Learn to identify these qualities in yourself and others, discover which organs are associated with the elements and learn tips for each season that will help to support your health. You'll also experience a mini auricular treatment designed to balance all of the elements and create a relaxed, harmonic state.

The attendees will learn:

- The 5 elements and the seasons with which they are associated

-Virtues of the 5 elements when in balance

-Signs and symptoms of imbalanced elements

-Tips for self care for best health throughout the seasons

Sarah Heiber is a licensed acupuncturist (L.Ac) and Diplomate of Acupuncture (Dipl. Ac) practicing at Life Balance Acupuncture in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Her interest in acupuncture stems from a life long interest in medicine, languages, and cultures. After receiving acupuncture for knee pain and anxiety, she was amazed at how life changing and transforming this kind of medicine was. She left her job teaching ESL to pursue her degree in Acupuncture to help others the way treatment had helped her.

To schedule an appointment visit www.LifeBalanceAcu.com

The LSG Metaphysical Lectures is a once monthly meetup that spotlights local Metaphysical, Alternative Wellness, or Spiritual practitioners.

As always there will be cupcakes for sale after the event!

To see future presenters visit www.lsglb.com
results.name: LSG Lectures -5 Seasonal Elements & Your Health with Acupuncturist Sarah Heiber

results.description:
Please join Pittsburgh Opera and your Meet Up friends for Igor Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress -- with a special discount ticket offer for several performances at the Benedum Center on Tuesday, May 3 at 7:00pm, Friday, May 6 at 7:30pm, and Sunday, May 8 at 2:00pm.

Pittsburgh Opera concludes its 77th season with the Pittsburgh premiere of the David Hockney production of Stravinsky’s THE RAKE’S PROGRESS. The plot follows Tom Rakewell, who squanders his large inheritance on women, drinking and gambling.

Tom’s journey from fortunate heir, to gambler, to inmate at Bedlam is based on a famous series of engravings by William Hogarth from 1732. The opera itself is by Igor Stravinsky, who was inspired by Hogarth’s engravings. It premiered in 1951. The libretto was written by poets W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman. Pittsburgh Opera is performing the David Hockney production, with jaw-dropping sets, props, wigs and costumes designed by “the most influential British artist of all time”. Hockney mimics the feel of Hogarth’s original engravings, using black cross hatching and the three colors printers used in Hogarth’s time: red, blue and green.

The performances are essentially a living David Hockney art installation set to Stravinsky’s beautiful neo-classical music.

Check out these example videos

https://youtu.be/DxeeWlp4AZ8?list=PL3yrlvmdaUwiI-c_A6zVEqA-FbGOnP469

https://youtu.be/wHawoT77ZV8?list=PL3yrlvmdaUwiI-c_A6zVEqA-FbGOnP469

Check out the great articles and reviews about the show http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2016/05/01/Review-Pittsburgh-Opera-mounts-Stravinsky-s-The-Rake-Progress-in-high-style/stories/201605010231

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/10373435-74/opera-stravinsky-rakewell

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2016/04/28/Pittsburgh-Opera-acquires-colorful-production-from-San-Francisco-that-was-almost-discarded/stories/201604280009

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/10333255-74/opera-rake-progress

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2016/04/28/Music-Preview-Recalling-the-American-premiere-of-Stravinsky-s-magnificent-The-Rake-s-Progress/stories/201604280006

http://wesa.fm/post/pittsburgh-operas-rakes-progress-bridges-distant-centuries

Meetup Ticket Discount Offer

Pittsburgh Opera is very graciously offering the Meetup a fantastic deal for great seats for a wonderful experience with powerful music and stunning set/costumes.

And for even more flexibility, Pittsburgh Opera is offering the discount for two performance dates (so we'll be scheduling Meetup dates for each one) 

  Tuesday, May 3 at 7 PM 

  Friday, May 6 at 7:30 PM

  Sunday, May 8 at 2 PM

Meetup members can purchase tickets to either performance for the following special prices:

$40 for best available in Sections A & B (regularly $102.75 to $157.75 in value) which are equivalent to the best seats on the Orchestra Floor or Directors Circle with fantastic views to the stage.

$20 for best available in Sections C & D (regularly $42.75 to $79.75) which are equivalent to really good seats on the Orchestra Floor or First Tier/lower Second Tier in the balcony with great views to the stage.

This is a very generous offer and a wonderful opportunity to experience opera, especially for those that perhaps have never checked out classic opera before.  Naturally, this offer is not intended to be a substitute for Pittsburgh Opera[masked] subscriptions which also have many benefits.

If you prefer going on Friday, May 6 or Sunday, May 8 instead, please RSVP to other Meetup posting http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/230509864/

With this special Meetup offer, please note that you will be seated on the day of the show with the best available seating in your selected sections. Pick up your tickets at the Benedum Center Box Office Will Call starting 2 hours before your performance.  To take advantage of this special Meetup offer, please go online https://pct.formstack.com/forms/operaforms_op16_meet_up_offer_the_rakes_progress Just click "Continue" below and follow the steps to place your order. Confirm your seating selection, then select the number of seats, and provide your contact/billing information. You will receive an email confirming that your order has been received and containing a transaction number as a reference. If you have any questions, please contact Randy Adams, Group Services Manager, PITTSBURGH OPERA[masked] x213 or [masked] or [masked].

If you want to check out photos of seating views to the stage inside the Benedum at various ticket price points, here is the link https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/performance/44075/tiers/show

As an additional note -- and for those that might be looking to buy the cheapest possible ticket ($13-$21 plus ticket handling charges but with no discount) -- please know that you can do this easily yourself by going online https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/production/44071/list_performances or call (412)[masked], or stopping buy the Theater Square/Benedum Box Office.  Also, we'll post comments later on to let people know if the cheapest possible tickets will still be available at the door or if the show will approach a sell out.

The Meetup ticket offer is a really good deal, so definitely think about treating yourself or bringing family/friends for a truly memorable evening.

UNDERSTAND EVERY WORD! This opera is sung in English with English texts projected above the stage. For this reason, the really good seats have both great views to the stage and the text above the stage. 

For more information about "The Rake's Progress" including song/video samples, photos, cast/artistic team, synopsis, etc. please visit http://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/the-rakes-progress

For more information about Russian composer Igor Stravinsky, please visit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky

PRE-SHOW DISCUSSION Your ticket also includes a very interesting pre-show discussion (including a colorful study guide) which begins one hour before every performance inside the theater. Thus, we shall plan to meet inside the Benedum at 6 PM (on Tuesday, May 2) for this discussion.

And if you can't make it on Tuesday, May 3 or Friday, May 6 or Sunday, May 8 performances with the Meetup ticket offer, please consider attending one of the other performances of "The Rake's Progress"

  Saturday, April 30 at 8 PM

  Tuesday, May 3 at 7 PM

  Friday, May 6 at 7:30 PM

  Sunday, May 8 at 2 PM

Normally priced tickets and ticket availability for all performances may be found at https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/production/44071/list_performances

AFTER-SHOW Cast Q&A Discussion with complimentary tea/coffee When the show ends, please feel free to go downstairs inside the Benedum for complimentary coffee/tea while cast members join us to discuss their experiences in performing "The Rake's Progress" along with some insight about their training, other performances they've been doing around the world, their fun experiences while visiting Pittsburgh, etc. These cast Q&A discussions are often very funny and engaging. This is also a chance to see these opera stars out of costume and actually being quite down-to-earth in addition to their remarkable talents. These Q&A discussions can last 30-60 minutes including  a chance for photos and autographs if desired. 

Normally priced tickets and ticket availability for all performances may be found at https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/production/44071/list_performances 

Other Discount Offers Discount tickets are also available through Goldstar https://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/pittsburgh-pa/the-rakes-progress-tickets where you can save about 50% for various seating locations for all 4 performances (April 30-May 8, 2016).

FYI, here are other upcoming shows where Goldstar has access to discount tickets http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite While Goldstar is not a substitute for more traditional savings/benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers (including what we can sometimes arrange for ourselves for Meetup), it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. For more background/FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Forbes, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/company Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.

Don't miss this wonderful experience!

Stay tuned for updates!

results.description:
This is not a formal meetup. We share this information with you because it is a metaphysics event in Pittsburgh that you may enjoy attending.

Here the details about the event:

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People

First Wednesday of Every Month

* 1pm - 7pm *

Union Project: Great Hall

801 N Negley Avenue

Pittsburgh, PA 15206

Contact information:
Tel:[masked]
​Mail: [masked]

Visit our Facebook Page!

Please contact us if you plan to attend and would like to receive holistic health services (or if you would like to volunteer).

Location & Hours THREE RIVERS FREE CLINIC FOR THE PEOPLE!

A holistic health FREE clinic serving the people in Pittsburgh and surrounding areas.

Jan. 7 Schedule of Services to be posted soon.

Mission

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People is a community service for individuals unable to afford or easily access to holistic healthcare. Together we deliver the future of healthcare by caring for the community who represent our individual well being for the sake of the generations to come.

Description

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People or TRFCP, is a community based service concerning individuals unable to afford or have easy access to holistic healthcare. Developed to support our elders who represent our roots and traditions, warriors who represent and defend our nation, "tree" women who represent the diversity of women who struggle through sexual, physical, mental and emotional abuse, and children in need, who represent our future and inspiration.

The vision of TRFCP is supported by Herbalist's without Borders, The Union Project and Ola's Herb Shop who have collaborated with the understanding that the importance to provide this kind of space to support all members of the community is paramount. All people reflect our individual selves, therefore our societal health. In addition, access to holistic health interventions are not always accessible and available to everyone, yet are traditionally and scientifically proven to be highly effective forms of healing from which many can benefit.

The clinic will be available once a month and individuals will sign-up or have scheduled visits (particularly groups coming from a facility or organization).

Current days are every first Wednesday of the month, hours 1-7p.

Expect to be supported by volunteer practitioner(s) of holistic health who may provide botanical therapy, meditation, Reiki, intuitive counseling, yoga, massage therapy, reflexology and much more depending on the needs of the people and the practitioners who have volunteered their services for that day.

It is our hope that all forms of donations, through service, volunteer work or financial bases from interested members of the community, will sustain this vision because it is forseen to create a paradigm shift in community healthcare and delivery for the sake of us all.

results.description:
You don't have to look very far to see where we've strayed, as a culture.  So many of us have lost a real nature connection in our lives.

And more and more, studies are turning up that many of our present ailments and mental issues are often directly linked to the time we do or do not spend outdoors.  (Turns out most of us are normal after all, we're just lacking in our "Vitamin N!")


This is an introductory class, as I will be offering more in-depth workshops and field trips where we go into the local forests and work one on one with the plants and wildlife, etc.

But this evening's class will revolve around basic things we can do to really get the most out of our experience outside and the domino effect this can have on our personal and emotional lives.

Topics will be loosely based around things such as meditation, ceremony + the hows and whys that we should use it, finding our plant allies, dreams and how indigenous cultures used dreaming as a means of learning and connecting with nature, moon cycles, astrological significance, and much more.


As usual, I make each class approachable for each person.  No one should feel intimidated or concerned that they are in any way "too much of a beginner."  You do not have to be a yoga master or even capable of meditating to gain some useful information from this session.  We all come from many various backgrounds, and we all have something unique to share!

Feel free to leave any comments or questions below!  Hope to see you there!  :-)

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance because you know you are attending. (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!


What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

results.description:
George Washington's inauguration was a breaking news story for _The Pittsburgh Gazette_. When Pittsburgh's African-American soldiers returned home after World War I, the story was page 1 in the new _Pittsburgh Gazette Times_. At times of national tragedy, such as the sinking of the Lusitania in 1915, Gazette writers found local angles to bring the story home to readers. Those reports -- gleaned from Gazette archives that go back to 1786 -- are not so much hidden history; rather, they are history at risk of being forgotten. And that would be unfortunate.

These tales deserve another reading. They show how ordinary and extraordinary people responded to challenges. They include anecdotes that offer insights into the character of historical figures. They show us what daily life was like in and around Pittsburgh during war and peace. A journalist since 1970, Len Barcousky, recently retired from _The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette_, gathered many of those reports for his new book, _Hidden History of Pittsburgh_, and will share some of those tales at this program.

*We will meet in the Washington Elementary School auditorium.*

Refreshments will be served.

FREE! Everyone is welcome!
results.name: Hidden History of Pittsburgh

group.name: Free and Almost Free in Pittsburgh

results.description:
***20 people fit at our table, anyone who is still on the wait list day of book club can still come and sit at the bar adjacent to our book club table. There is room there to dine and conversation with the group.


Please Bring a Chick Lit/Women's Fiction book suggestion if you have one. Please check that is out in paperback and not published too recent so its more cost effective to purchase and easier to get from the library!

Not sure what to bring?

Definition of Chick Lit: Chick lit is genre fiction within women's fiction which addresses issues of modern women often humorously and lightheartedly Definition of Women's Fiction: a modern novel about a woman on the brink of life change and personal growth. Her journey details emotional reflection and action that transforms her and her relationships with others, and usually includes a hopeful/upbeat ending with regard to her romantic relationship.

Before there were blogs, there were journals. And in them we’d write as we really were, not as we wanted to appear. But there comes a day when journals outlive us. And with them, our secrets.

Summer vacation on Great Rock Island was supposed to be a restorative time for Kate, who’d lost her close friend Elizabeth in a sudden accident. But when she inherits a trunk of Elizabeth's journals, they reveal a woman far different than the cheerful wife and mother Kate thought she knew.
The complicated portrait of Elizabeth—her troubled upbringing, and her route to marriage and motherhood—makes Kate question not just their friendship, but her own deepest beliefs about loyalty and honesty at a period of uncertainty in her own marriage. When an unfamiliar man’s name appears in the pages, Kate realizes the extent of what she didn’t know about her friend, including where she was really going on the day she died.


The more Kate reads, the more she learns the complicated truth of who Elizabeth really was, and rethinks her own choices as a wife, mother, and professional, and the legacy she herself would want to leave behind.

results.description:
The Thurs., May 5 Biophilia: Pittsburgh meeting will feature Phipps staff members Charity Grimes Bauman and Gabe Tilove, who will lead a discussion on "Addressing Health and Food Security Through Home Vegetable Gardens." Phipps' Homegrown program has been working since 2013 to help Homewood residents grow fresh vegetables in their backyards. Home vegetable gardens help families incorporate more fresh produce into their meals at a low cost, engage in a healthy activity in their home environment, and provide an opportunity to build and share gardening skills with family and friends. Homegrown installs raised beds gardens filled with clean soil to overcome soil contamination issues prevalent across urban environments. Beyond the physical infrastructure we provide, we put a strong emphasis on skill building, creating communities of gardeners, and improving a community’s garden resources – all with an eye towards helping residents become confident, self-sufficient gardeners.  

With over 90 home gardens installed, Homegrown recently completed a professionally assisted program evaluation. Program staff Charity Grimes Bauman and Gabe Tilove will provide an overview of the program, share impacts and lessons gleaned from the evaluation, and discuss the decision to take a community-based approach for this program.

Meeting Schedule:  
5:30 – 6 p.m.            Networking and refreshments 
6 – 6:30 p.m.            Presentation 
6:30 – 7:30 p.m.      Discussion

Directions and Parking:  
This meeting will take place in the Center for Sustainable Landscapes (CSL) Classroom which is located on the facility’s first floor. The main Conservatory entrance will be closed, as this meeting takes place after normal hours; to access the CSL, follow Frew Street (located between the Oakland/Schenley Park bridge and the Christopher Columbus statue), which will take you around the Conservatory to the lower campus. Guest parking spaces are available on your left as you approach the CSL.
results.name: Biophilia: Pittsburgh May Meeting: Health, Food Security and Home Gardens

results.description:
Beaver County along with its community partners: the Borough of Midland, the City of Aliquippa; the Borough of Monaca; and Moon Township have joined together to undertake a grass-roots effort to re-think the future of our communities as a way to respond to the changes in our manufacturing/industrial base and the post-industrial brownfields legacy that remains. 

Beaver County on behalf of the communities received a $600,000 federal grant from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to undertake environmental assessments of known or perceived brownfield sites, develop site redevelopment plans, and identify infrastructure improvements needed to stimulate revitalization. 

This effort is a continuation of the U.S. EPA Funded Ohio River Brownfields Area-Wide Plan which was outcome of the Ohio River Trail Corporation’s initiative to provide increased access to and along the Ohio River corridor and the revitalization of the numerous blighted parcels, many of which are perceived brownfields.

The first public open house/meeting in Monaca is scheduled for: Thursday May 5th , 2016 from 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM at the Monaca Borough Building located at 928 Pennsylvania Avenue. Please stop by and review initial findings and contribute your ideas!
results.name: Ohio River Brownfields Project Public Information Meeting

results.description:
Join us for the April 2016 meeting of the County Barn Beekeeping Club!  This is forum for local beekeepers to get together and support each other.  We meet the first Thursday of the month from 6 to 7:30 pm.  Pre-registration via Meetup.com is required.  The informational part of the meeting will be a discussion of how to make splits and prevent swarms led by local beekeeper Perry Arlia. Perry is a longtime beekeeper, as well as past president of the Washington County Beekeepers Association and a member of the Western PA Beekeeping Seminar Committe.  We will also taste a single varietal honey as part of the meeting.  We taste a different honey at every meeting we have for the club as a fun activity.  If you would like to bring a varietal honey to introduce and taste or lead the monthly discussion, please contact Joe Zgurzynski, the meeting organizer.

Please note that we will be meeting at the Cooper-Siegel Community Library!  Please note that some gps systems do not route correctly to this address.  Here are directions from Route 28:

• Take exit 8 toward Fox Chapel

• Turn left onto Fox Chapel Rd and travel approximately 1.8 miles

• Destination will be on the left.

Cooper-Siegel Community Library, 403 Fox Chapel Rd, Pittsburgh, PA 15238

Phone:  [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the lower level program room.  You can park in back of the library for easy access. There is additional parking at the Fox Chapel Borough building next door.  Please note that GPS systems may not work, directions are listed below.

results.description:
Come join the Pittsburgh Change Ringing guild for an open house night to check out the bells. This is a great night for ringing novices to check out what change ringing is all about and the history of our 960 LB bells!

Non-Ringers can also have an opportunity to try pulling the bell under the guidance of an experienced bell ringer. We are more than happy to teach you the ancient art of bell ringing.
When entering the tower, the most important rule is DO NOT touch the ropes unless specifically instructed to by an experienced bell ringer. If people are currently ringing the bells when you walk in the room, please come in quietly and have a seat around the edges of the room. We will stop ringing in a few minutes, and can give you an introduction to the bells.

Learning to ring the bells does take some time before you would be able to ring comfortably on your own. Obviously the more effort you put into it the more quickly you would be able to ring confidently on your own. You can expect 4-6 weeks of individual instruction to get to that stage. And then once you learn how to handle the bells, that opens up a lifetime of ringing opportunities!

Check out the videos below to see what the bell ringing is like, and you are more than welcome to come join us for our practice night! Please RSVP if you are coming, because practices sometimes get cancelled for various reasons.

Bells swinging: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liuRptmR088
Ringers pulling ropes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M1vSfNF7OfI
results.name: Open House for New Ringers

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."
results.name: Fight Club: Ready ... Set ... Action!

results.description:
One Hour Sightseeing Cruise

 The Best Pittsburgh Tour is aboard our Pittsburgh Riverboat!


The only way to see the City of Pittsburgh and truly learn about her past, present and future is aboard one of our Pittsburgh Sightseeing Cruise.  Your Pittsburgh riverboat tour will begin on the Monongahela River and will continue on both the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers* all while our Captain and Narrator relay interesting facts, tales and river lore that make Pittsburgh and Western Pennsylvania so special.

Plus, on all of our Pittsburgh Sightseeing Tours we feature tasty snacks, cold drinks an cocktails to enjoy a day or evening out on the water!

You can order a ticket online to insure you get on but I doubt they'll sell out. I think I'll wait to purchase once we get closer to see the weather situation. If it's going to rain, we can try another date. 

The cruise takes off at 12:15 so I want to meet by 11:30 in front of the boat so we can get good spots. 

I was hoping to take a ride on the incline while we're there for some shots from Mt Washington. You can also go on a nighttime cruise and post your photos. 

Adult: $21.00
Child: $10.50

*Ticket price shown includes taxes and service charges. Menus, prices, dates and times are subject to change.

As always, any suggestions to make this meet up better, are welcome!
results.name: Gateway Clipper Fleet Pittsburgh Sightseeing Cruise.   **NOTE THIS IS A FRIDAY**

Hosted by Marcie O'Malley of Coldwell Banker Real Estate and Miriah Makowski from Farmers Insurance

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Natrona Heights area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 <a>business cards</a> or marketing material

- cash for your lunch <a>check</a>

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial and provide the following information.

- Your goal for attending or
- What is a good referral for you or
- Name one product or service they offer that will specifically help small <a>business</a> owners or business professionals.

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their <a>business card</a>

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi or Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs.Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please email Kimfitnesschic at [masked]

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact <a>Debi Arnett</a> at [masked]

If you are unable to attend, then please change your RSVP. Any non member that RSVPs and does not attend will be removed from this site.

results.description:
Hello Western PA Gamers!


Looks like we found another venue for the Western PA gaming meetups!  

A new attendance record for one of our events saw 26 gamers enjoying the April 22nd event.  With that kind of turnout I think we are going to look at having bi-weekly events here at the Market District in Settler's Ridge.    

The venue has a nice variety of hot food, snacks, Starbucks, beer, wine, and is open 24 hours!  

It is first come first serve on the seating but as members begin arriving at 5:00 we can throw some games on the larger tables to reserve them.  The venue probably has over twenty tables and the room can comfortably hold over 60 people.  It gets a little crowded at dinner time but thins out after 7:00 or so and is pretty much empty after 9:00.  


This is a great centrally located spot where our Airport area players can get to quickly as well as the Northern and City players. This location is probably only 15-20 minutes from the Fort Pitt tunnel.  

A little about what we play...

Today's board games come in all different shapes, sizes, themes, components, and our group plays all kinds.. Here are some examples of the types of games we play... 


Party games like:  Codenames, Spyfall, and Dixit.

Euro style games like:  Five Tribes, Orleans, Puerto Rico, Viticulture, and Lords of Waterdeep.

Cooperative games like:  Pandemic, Flash Point, and Dead of Winter.

Abstract games like:  Qwirkle, Blokus, and Hive.

Card games like:  Dominion, Glory to Rome, Diamonds and Muchkin.

Those are just a few of the games that can be seen being played at our meetups every week.

Our members come in all shapes and sizes and span from young to older but all seem to have a great time when we get together!

Our organizers try to be very accommodating to new players and try to pick games appropriate to your skill level and that we think you would enjoy.  Our goal is to get you enthusiastic about the hobby.

If there is a game that you would like to try out just r.s.v.p. to one of our meetups and suggest it down in the chat.  Chances are that one of us has it in our collection and we can bring it out.

Look forward to introducing the hobby to many more players in 2016 and continued good times with our regulars.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans. 

See you soon!

Russ.

RE-Model Gala is a recycle-themed art and dance fashion show, featuring bellydancers modeling designs made by local artists, using all recycled, recyclable, reused, reusable and/or otherwise eco-friendly materials. Eco-friendly prizes from local businesses will be awarded to winning artist(s). results.description:
Come - let us learn how to play American Mah Jongg or seriously play Mah Jongg and have some fun.  Please post that you are a beginner if you need instructions.  I suggest beginners try to get there by 6 pm to allow time to learn and then have a game or two after that. But come whenever you can.

If you plan to eat, try to come earlier or finish your food before you sit in for a game. I found out that Mah Jongg is not a good game to be eating and playing at the same time. Since we are using the facilities of Panera, no outside food or drinks please.  Also please purchase a drink or snack or food to support them for allowing us to use their facilities.


Another group has already reserved the Community Room, so the manager said we could use the bigger round tables outside the Room. It will still be in the back area of the restaurant.


This Panera is on the ground floor of the Quality Inn Hotel. It also has a free parking lot and is on exit 376 to Bates Street to Blvd of the Allies. So it is not right into the narrow, crowded streets of Oakland.

results.description:
Please join Pittsburgh Opera and your Meet Up friends for Igor Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress -- with a special discount ticket offer for several performances at the Benedum Center on Tuesday, May 3 at 7:00pm, Friday, May 6 at 7:30pm, and Sunday, May 8 at 2:00pm.

Pittsburgh Opera concludes its 77th season with the Pittsburgh premiere of the David Hockney production of Stravinsky’s THE RAKE’S PROGRESS. The plot follows Tom Rakewell, who squanders his large inheritance on women, drinking and gambling.

Tom’s journey from fortunate heir, to gambler, to inmate at Bedlam is based on a famous series of engravings by William Hogarth from 1732. The opera itself is by Igor Stravinsky, who was inspired by Hogarth’s engravings. It premiered in 1951. The libretto was written by poets W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman. Pittsburgh Opera is performing the David Hockney production, with jaw-dropping sets, props, wigs and costumes designed by “the most influential British artist of all time”. Hockney mimics the feel of Hogarth’s original engravings, using black cross hatching and the three colors printers used in Hogarth’s time: red, blue and green.

The performances are essentially a living David Hockney art installation set to Stravinsky’s beautiful neo-classical music.

Check out these example videos

https://youtu.be/DxeeWlp4AZ8?list=PL3yrlvmdaUwiI-c_A6zVEqA-FbGOnP469

https://youtu.be/wHawoT77ZV8?list=PL3yrlvmdaUwiI-c_A6zVEqA-FbGOnP469

Check out the great articles and reviews about the show http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2016/05/01/Review-Pittsburgh-Opera-mounts-Stravinsky-s-The-Rake-Progress-in-high-style/stories/201605010231

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/10373435-74/opera-stravinsky-rakewell

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2016/04/28/Pittsburgh-Opera-acquires-colorful-production-from-San-Francisco-that-was-almost-discarded/stories/201604280009

http://triblive.com/aande/theaterarts/10333255-74/opera-rake-progress

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2016/04/28/Music-Preview-Recalling-the-American-premiere-of-Stravinsky-s-magnificent-The-Rake-s-Progress/stories/201604280006

http://wesa.fm/post/pittsburgh-operas-rakes-progress-bridges-distant-centuries

Meetup Ticket Discount Offer

Pittsburgh Opera is very graciously offering the Meetup a fantastic deal for great seats for a wonderful experience with powerful music and stunning set/costumes.

And for even more flexibility, Pittsburgh Opera is offering the discount for two performance dates (so we'll be scheduling Meetup dates for each one) 

  Tuesday, May 3 at 7 PM 

  Friday, May 6 at 7:30 PM

  Sunday, May 8 at 2 PM

Meetup members can purchase tickets to either performance for the following special prices:

$40 for best available in Sections A & B (regularly $102.75 to $157.75 in value) which are equivalent to the best seats on the Orchestra Floor or Directors Circle with fantastic views to the stage.

$20 for best available in Sections C & D (regularly $42.75 to $79.75) which are equivalent to really good seats on the Orchestra Floor or First Tier/lower Second Tier in the balcony with great views to the stage.

This is a very generous offer and a wonderful opportunity to experience opera, especially for those that perhaps have never checked out classic opera before.  Naturally, this offer is not intended to be a substitute for Pittsburgh Opera[masked] subscriptions which also have many benefits.

If you prefer going on Tuesday, May 3, please RSVP to other Meetup posting http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/230509788/

With this special Meetup offer, please note that you will be seated on the day of the show with the best available seating in your selected sections. Pick up your tickets at the Benedum Center Box Office Will Call starting 2 hours before your performance.  To take advantage of this special Meetup offer, please go online https://pct.formstack.com/forms/operaforms_op16_meet_up_offer_the_rakes_progress Just click "Continue" below and follow the steps to place your order. Confirm your seating selection, then select the number of seats, and provide your contact/billing information. You will receive an email confirming that your order has been received and containing a transaction number as a reference. If you have any questions, please contact Randy Adams, Group Services Manager, PITTSBURGH OPERA[masked] x213 or [masked] or [masked].

If you want to check out photos of seating views to the stage inside the Benedum at various ticket price points, here is the link https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/performance/44075/tiers/show

As an additional note -- and for those that might be looking to buy the cheapest possible ticket ($13-$21 plus ticket handling charges but with no discount) -- please know that you can do this easily yourself by going online https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/production/44071/list_performances or call (412)[masked], or stopping buy the Theater Square/Benedum Box Office.  Also, we'll post comments later on to let people know if the cheapest possible tickets will still be available at the door or if the show will approach a sell out.

The Meetup ticket offer is a really good deal, so definitely think about treating yourself or bringing family/friends for a truly memorable evening.

UNDERSTAND EVERY WORD! This opera is sung in English with English texts projected above the stage. For this reason, the really good seats have both great views to the stage and the text above the stage. 

For more information about "The Rake's Progress" including song/video samples, photos, cast/artistic team, synopsis, etc. please visit http://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/the-rakes-progress

For more information about Russian composer Igor Stravinsky, please visit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky

PRE-SHOW DISCUSSION Your ticket also includes a very interesting pre-show discussion (including a colorful study guide) which begins one hour before every performance inside the theater. Thus, we shall plan to meet inside the Benedum at 6:30 PM on Friday, May 6 or 1 PM on Sunday, May 8 for this discussion.

And if you can't make it on Tuesday, May 3 or Friday, May 6 or Sunday, May 8 performances with the Meetup ticket offer, please consider attending one of the other performances of "The Rake's Progress"

  Saturday, April 30 at 8 PM

  Tuesday, May 3 at 7 PM

  Friday, May 6 at 7:30 PM

  Sunday, May 8  at 2 PM

Normally priced tickets and ticket availability for all performances may be found at https://opera.culturaldistrict.org/production/44071/list_performances

Other Discount Offers Discount tickets are also available through Goldstar https://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/pittsburgh-pa/the-rakes-progress-tickets where you can save about 50% for various seating locations for all 4 performances (April 30-May 8, 2016).

FYI, here are other upcoming shows where Goldstar has access to discount tickets http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite While Goldstar is not a substitute for more traditional savings/benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers (including what we can sometimes arrange for ourselves for Meetup), it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. For more background/FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Forbes, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/company Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.

Don't miss this wonderful experience!

Stay tuned for updates!

7:00 PM: Doors open and time to settle in/warm-up
7:20 PM: Opening circle
~7:35 PM: Free-form dancing begins!
~8:45 PM: Closing circle

This event is hosted by Ecstatic Dance Pittsburgh. Check us out & follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/456312731245106/

[cross-posted from Free and Almost Free in Pittsburgh]

Join two amazing nonprofits (PA Resources Council and Allegheny CleanWays) for the kickoff event of our 2016 Films for a Better Planet Film Series! We will be screening Racing to Zero followed by a panel discussion with local experts. Racing to Zero shows us how the city of San Francisco is taking steps to go completely zero waste (not send any materials to landfill) by 2020. Come learn more about how we can view “trash” as a resource. Stick around afterwards for a panel discussion with experts from the Pittsburgh area!

While at the event head on over to the tasting room or a Wigle Whiskey cocktail or visit the Franktuary Food Truck for quality hot dogs! (Vegan options available). Help us embrace zero waste by bringing your own water bottle and cutlery!

Event is free but you MUST REGISTER. Space is limited! Register here - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/films-for-a-better-planet-racing-to-zero-screening-and-discussion-tickets-24025818871

results.description:
The Workshop
Come prepared for a great discussion on remote research and testing. The methods up for discussion include: Interviews conducted via phone, Skype or Web conference; Usability tests via talk-aloud moderated protocols and using un-moderated tools; talk-aloud moderated card sorts and using un-moderated tools; and more! This session will introduce each topic and the facilitator will encourage you to share your experience, swap stories and of course learn from each other. You'll leave with broad knowledge about the challenges and tricks to successful remote research and testing.

About Carol
The facilitator, Carol Smith conducted her first remote studies in 2004 and has been researching to understand user needs and then advocating for improved designs on their behalf for 15 years. She has led projects for the US government, non-profits and corporations in a wide variety of industries. Her efforts have improved user's experiences of mobile apps, Web sites, software, consumer goods and services. She currently manages a large team of design professionals with skills across the spectrum of UX (from early user/design research, through interaction design and into visual design) at IBM Watson.Carol has a Master's degree in Human-Computer Interaction from DePaul University and is an active UX community organizer.

Whats Included 
The cost of attendance will cover the workshop, a light breakfast and lunch. Menu TBD, please message or email Erica Hayes with any special dietary needs. [masked]

Childcare Available
On-site childcare is available to attendees for an additional $20. Professional daycare staff will set-up shop to watch the kiddos. Please message Erica Hayes if you plan on utilizing their service so that we can add your child to the attendance list. [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Shared entry with Silk Elephant restaurant, go to the 3rd floor and use entrance to the left.
results.name: Workshop: Getting the Most out of Remote Research and Testing

results.description: Performance Bikes in Pittsburgh is again hosting a weekly Intermediate Ride. Yay! Join other cyclists in your community on this scenic, moderately challenging ride. Average pace is 14-16 miles per hour with a ride duration of approximately 1 hour. The intermediate route includes light urban riding, local bike paths, and residential riding. We tackle hills as they come and include at least one more challenging climb (read: over 1 mile in length). The Intermediate Ride provides an opportunity to meet new riding partners, share and build knowledge, and get a workout. This is a no-drop ride. Seasoned and very fit riders can increase ride difficulty by getting out of the saddle on climbs, as well as by down-shifting and spinning at higher cadence to build muscle suppleness. Rides start and end at the shop. Look forward to welcoming new faces this season!
results.name: Join us for an Intermediate Bike Ride

group.name: Performance Bicycle Great Ride Series: Pittsburgh

results.description:
The first Urban Hike of 2016 is in the Manchester and Chateau neighborhoods of Pittsburgh.

This hike will be part of the international event called Jane's Walk, which commemorates Jane Jacobs, the author of The Death and Life of Great American Cities. The hike will feature how Manchester and Chateau were once a connected neighborhood that was severed by highway expansions. The thriving Beaver Street business district was completely demolished to make way for the highway. Before and after pictures will be shown at the hike.

The hike is about 3 miles long and it should last between 2 and 3 hours. We will visit Bicycle Heaven and learn about some old and recent housing developments in the neighborhood. The hike will end at Allegheny and Western Avenue with multiple points available for lunch.

As always, we hike rain, shine, or cold, so be sure to bring the appropriate gear. This hike will be mostly flat, with one exception of a set of steps near the West End Bridge.

If you are driving to the hike, please be advised to parking restrictions on the streets and in parking lots. We suggest looking for parking in the residential area of Manchester to the northwest of the meeting point (in the vicinity of the 1000 block of W. North Ave). We also recommend walking, biking, taking public transportation, and carpooling! The starting location is a short walk from the Allegheny T Station that provides free service from Downtown.

We look forward to seeing you on May 7th!

Not familiar with Urban Hike? Learn more at urbanhike.com or facebook.com/urbanhike.
results.name: Urban Hike in Manchester and Chateau

results.description:
Pittsburgh Trolleys in 3D program this Saturday!!! ALL INVITED!!!
"Pittsburgh Trolleys in 3D" Saturday, May 7th,[masked]am - 1pm at the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh - Beechview, 1910 Broadway Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15216
Beechview native and historian, Edward Falvo will present a 3D slide presentation using original "3-dimensional" Stereo Realist Slides taken during the 1960s and early 70s. Trolley memorabilia, collectibles and toy trains will be on display. Vintage Pittsburgh Railways Co. and early Port Authority pamphlets & literature compliment the display.
Do you remember the 42/38 Mt. Lebanon/Beechview, the 43 Neeld or the 42 Dormont trolley? Come and see some memories from your childhood.
Light refreshments will be served. This free event is a Pittsburgh 200 event and suitable for all ages!
Sponsored by the Beechview Historical Society with support from the Beechview Area Concerned Citizens.
results.name: Learn about Pittsburgh Trolley history

results.description: This meeting is to get together and converse in the Russian Language. Whether a beginner, intermediate or advanced/native speaker this will be a great opportunity to flex your Russian-speaking tongue. What better way to learn a language than to practice with some friends, laugh at your mistakes, and hear it straight from the mouth of a native speaker. This meetup will repeat every first Saturday of the month. If you can not make this meeting, then feel free to join us at our other requiring meetup on the third Thursday evening of every month. Have an idea for a meetup? Want to suggest a new time and/or location? Message me and we'll work out the details. До следующего времени, мои русскоязычные друзья!

results.description:
On May 7, 2016 the European Studies Center at Pitt's University Center for International Studies will be hosting its first ever Europe Day Festival! The festival, which will run from 12:00 PM – 7:30 PM in and around Posvar Hall (230 S. Bouquet Street), will be a celebration of European culture, cuisine, and heritage. Local artisans and vendors will create a dynamic marketplace and performances of regional song and dance will be presented on the main stage.  Artistic demonstrations, music and children’s activities will take place throughout the day.

Volunteers are also needed for set-up the morning of the event.  Volunteers will receive a T-shirt and a food voucher good at festival vendors, as well as our undying gratitude.  To volunteer, contact Kate: [masked]. 

Check out the following links for info about the food, performances, and other activities throughout the afternoon and early evening on Saturday, May 7

   - RESTAURANT AND FOOD VENDORS

   - ACTIVITIES, MARKETPLACE, AND SHOWCASE

   - PERFORMANCES

Meetup Considerations With over 7 hours of entertainment, a large crowd is expected while people will naturally be arriving and leaving at different times depending on what else people have planned for the day (for example, other shows, dinner, etc.)

We'll also consider options for the group to also check out nearby places in Oakland (for example, Carnegie Museums, Phipps Conservatory) or other activities such as the Pittonkatonk http://pittonkatonk.org/ free community event featuring many styles of brass music (with both local and touring musicians) including Balkan, New Orleans Jazz, Symphonic, and street bands as well as food and other activities which will be held outside (with a family friendly, potluck, picnic style BBQ atmosphere) near the Schenley Park Vietnam Veterans Pavilion.

If there are specific times/performances you're interested in, please feel free to post some comments below.

Suggested possible times for the group to gather: 12-1:30 PM (Mark, Event Host), 6-6:30 PM (Mark, Event Host)


As always, it is also OK if you prefer going on your own with family or friends instead.

Stay tuned for updates!
results.how_to_find_us: The group could meet during 12-2 PM, 6-6:30 PM perhaps at one of the other suggested times as mentioned in the Comments Section

results.description:
The Pittsburgh Vegan Festival is the city's largest vegan event, showcasing the best and most exciting vegan food, dessert, drinks, products and services, while also entertaining guests with cultural dance and music, wellness activities, games, kids' activities, guest speakers, cooking demos and more!

Bring money to spend on vendors! There will be so many great smells, visual displays, products, treats, foods, and activities drawing your attention, and you will definitely not want to leave empty-handed and especially not empty-bellied!

PITTSBURGH VEGAN FESTIVAL - SPRING EDITION

Sat. May 7, 2016

12- 7 p.m.

$5 admission (cash only, at the door)

Free for kids 12 and under. 

Wheelchair accessible.

Free parking lot. Carpooling is still recommended, if you are able, since we get a huge turnout.

No pets, please.

Location:

Unitarian Universalist Church of the North Hills

2359 W. Ingomar Rd. 15237

NOTE: This is the NORTH HILLS, not the north side.

For more information, please visit https://www.facebook.com/PittsburghVeganFestival

results.description:
What is Pittonkatonk?
Pittonkatonk is a grassroots effort to connect people through local and national brass-band music. Pittonkatonk is more than a day long concert in the park.

Working with over 100+ musicians throughout the year, we also provide ongoing educational programming and promote events in and around the city. The May Day Brass BBQ is held annually on the first Saturday in May (Saturday, May 7) in Schenley Park at the Vietnam Veterans Pavilion.

ALL AGES
FAMILY FRIENDLY
NO COVER
OPEN TO ALL
CONTRIBUTE TO THE POTLUCK
HOST A BAND
VOLUNTEER

This is a[masked] person All-Weather EVENT!!!
http://pittonkatonk.org/

THIS YEARS BANDS TBA!  Come to our Fundraising event if you wanna find out more...

https://www.facebook.com/events/1712612479013812/

many many more details to come.

results.description:
Cross-posted to the Pittsburgh area anxiety, shyness and depression meetup group.

We have scheduled the larger room for May's library talk.

Hope to see you there! The meeting will be a regular meeting, where we introduce ourselves and then discuss whatever topics related to anxiety or depression that we have going on. Please try to keep intros to five minutes or less so we can all give our intros and then move on to general discussion.

Paid parking is enforced on Saturdays on Brookline Blvd.


We also have movie night at Scott F's place later on that evening, but spots are filling quickly for that one, for those who want to see Office Space with the meetup group.
results.how_to_find_us: Zip code 15226
results.name: Let's Meet Up and Have a Talk at the Brookline Library

group.name: Let's End Isolation caused by depression, anxiety

results.description:
This opportunity to be playful and try out dramatic theater exercises is inclusive for people of all ages and abilities and welcomes those with special needs.  We offer large group circle exercises that incorporate imagination and movement. For example, in “Going to the City” each person in the circle gets a chance to say they are an item you would find in a city, such as a car, and then everyone in the circle pretends they are a car. These workshops also may include a taste of dialogue improv exercises, where people work with partners to learn the basics of creating an improvised scene.

You can guarantee your spot by registering at www.openuppittsburgh.com
results.name: Free Family Improv Games at the Arcade Comedy Theater!
