results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2016 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!
results.name: Mah Jong in Shadyside! (Note:  No beginner class tonight!)

results.description:
RSVP Here

https://www.showclix.com/event/protohype-kickoff

A Prototyping Competition

Learn how you can prototype to WIN $10,000! RSVP to learn more about TechShop Pittsburgh's 1st ever prototyping competition! In partnership with University of Pittsburgh - Clinical and Translational Science Institute, TechShop Pittsburgh is officially kicking off the ProtoHype competition on Tuesday, May 17th from 5:30pm - 8:00pm.​

5:30 - 6:15: Food & Networking

6:15 - 6:30: Competition Kick-off & Overview

6:30 - 7:30: Prototyping Challenges Presented

7:30 - 8:00: Q & A + Networking

This competition brings together the knowledge of challenging problems in the medical field, and pairs them with technical know-how of TechShop members and beyond. During this May 17th kick-off, we will be presenting the Top 10 prototyping challenges for which teams can compete to solve! We will discuss the rules of the competition, review the key dates, and answer audience questions.

The competition is open to anyone with technical know-how in the hardware field. Feel free to invite other members, hackers, tinkers, mad scientists, or anyone who you think could be interested in competing!

All the teams selected to compete will also be granted 1-Year TechShop Membership, free classes, and a material budget for prototyping.

Below you will find a quick overview & key dates for the competition.
-----

Quick overview:

Product ideas/concepts have been selected from U. of Pittsburgh's CTSI
Ideas focus on medical devices/tools
*All IP will be retained by U. of Pittsburgh*
Anyone can form a prototyping team to compete (2 to 4 people per team)
Prototyping teams can choose to prototype any of the available ideas
3 to 5 prototyping teams will be selected for the competition
The prototype is expected to be a functioning "proof of concept"
All participating teams will receive 1-year of Membership + Classes
$10,000 prize award to the winning team!

Timeline:

May 17th - Prototyping Challenges revealed
June 30th - Deadline for prototyping teams to apply
August 10th - Prototyping Teams selected
Aug. 11th - October 31st - Build Period
Nov. 9th - Winning Team Announced!

results.description:
Beekeeping Club member John Yakim will host an apiary tour.  Weather permitting, we will do a basic hive inspection.

This apiary tour is best suited for new beekeepers, non-beekeepers or current beekeepers with less than one year of experiance.   There is a chance that you could be stung while visit the hives.  Veils must be worn.  If you need to purchase a veil you can get one from Country Barn Farm by contacting <a>[masked]</a>.  We will inspecting hives as part of the tour the weather permits.  Please wear or bring a long sleeve shirt, long pants and closed toed shoes or boots.  If you need to use gloves, plan to wear new / disposable gloves to reduce the risk of disease transmission between apiaries. You will be asked to sign a release of liability form.  Be sure to bring two bottles of water to stay hydrated.  If you are under 18 a parent must register and attend with you.  Please follow this link: Release Form 

Please print out the form and bring a signed copy with you for you apiary tour host.

results.description:
Please ask at the host stand for the book club. We are usually in the back room against the windows, but you never know...

So sorry this took me so long to post!

From Amazon.com:

Lydia is dead. From the first sentence of Celeste Ng’s stunning debut, we know that the oldest daughter of the Chinese-American Lee family has died. What follows is a novel that explores alienation, achievement, race, gender, family, and identity--as the police must unravel what has happened to Lydia, the Lee family must uncover the sister and daughter that they hardly knew. There isn’t a false note in this book, and my only concern in describing my profound admiration for Everything I Never Told You is that it might raise unachievable expectations in the reader. But it’s that good. Achingly, precisely, and sensitively written. --Chris Schluep
results.why: We love to read, drink wine and talk about books!

The Ancestor Deep-Dive:  How You Can Find Out Everything There Possibly is to Know About Your Ancestor

This talk, presented by Tammy Hepps, will teach a methodology for creating a research plan centered around the discoveries we want to make, not the pathways we think are available for getting there.  The presentation will start with how to brainstorm what we want to know, and conclude with how to work backwards to determine what sources might contain the elusive information.  Ms. Hepps, from New York City, has presented at national conferences, including RootsTech 2015, and is a member of several genealogy society boards and advisory committees.

results.description:
Ever wonder how product development works inside of a successful startup? It’s fast-paced, it’s exciting, and it’s 100% focused on getting the right user feedback as quickly as possible.

In this session, we’ll dive into the methods startup companies use to bring successful products to market as quickly as possible all while incorporating feedback and minimizing their risk every step of the way. We’ll learn how to use techniques from both Lean Startup and Customer Development as well as how these processes can work together with common agile methodologies such as Scrum to define and shape great products all along the way.

Not in a startup? If you’re running on an agile cadence you can use these same techniques to create and refine new features for an existing product or even entirely new versions of that product. Come learn how the game of product development is changing and how you can make that work for you.
results.name: Building Great Products with Agile and Lean Startup

results.description:
What exactly is a "Moon Cycle?"  Though many women (and some men!) are familiar with this term, young teens and ladies in their early 20s may not yet have heard such a thing.  Dare I say some women who have already completed menopause may not even be familiar-- our culture just does. not. teach this.


A moon cycle is, at its most basic, the idea that the female menstrual cycle tends to follow certain phases of the moon.

I will also discuss the basic hormone routine that each woman finds herself a part of, every week of every month, before she reaches menopause.  The hormones are interesting, and they bounce up and down throughout each week, depending on where we're at in our cycle.  I will describe (with as much time as we have) the basic cycle each week and what to expect.  Did you know there are some weeks that women cannot even become pregnant?  This is the general idea behind the more familiar "charting" concept.Though I will not be able to get into the details in this one hour class, I would like to introduce these ideas so that interested ladies or guys may begin to understand the bigger picture. THIS IS AN AWESOME CLASS FOR TEENAGERS JUST ENTERING PUBERTY or anyone unaware of such cycles.  Boys should honestly learn this too, as a real method for understanding the women of all ages in their lives.  And don't worry, I'm not too awkward about these matters!  I teach all of my classes with an open mind and easy-going nature.  I am just here to assist in the learning process for all of us!

I also touch upon herbal solutions for irregular or imbalanced hormones.  I only wish I knew these as a teenager!!


I'd like to stress the importance that both women and men benefit a great deal from becoming aware of the lunar cycles.  For men, the significance of this rhythm can lie in life events and especially in connecting deeply with your partner (maybe especially if your partner is a female.)


As a woman, I find that my monthly cycle mirrors the cycle of the Moon.  And I believe this is how things always used to be, when women slept outside and found themselves closer in tune with this natural rhythm.


In this course, I will cover the significance of these rhythms and how they can be very healthy for us to follow and become aware of.  I strongly encourage men to attend these classes or workshops to learn how to better connect with and balance masculinity and femininity.


The knowledge of the lunar cycle can help us to understand ourselves and the world around us much better.  A few key points that this knowledge can assist us with are:  relationship understanding (understanding our partner-- or family members!), women's health (hormones and how our bodies function), and how to make better sense of the world and why certain things may tend to happen at certain times and certain moons.


I like to discuss some astrology in this course too, to delve a bit deeper.

The moon will be waxing in Libra this particular evening, a fine time to discuss these matters :-)
results.name: May Bridgeville Library Free Series:  Moon Cycles & Fertility Awareness

This award-winning book tells the true story of her ancestors' westward migration from Vermont to Western Pennsylvania to Northern California through a series of letters written by members of the Phillips family from 1842 - 1962. results.name: Pioneer Life: A Journey in Correspondence

results.description:
For our May meeting, we'll start our summer tour of places where we can sit outside by meeting at Panera.  And I hope we can continue this through September!  We will definitely have one meeting at California Pizza Kitchen.  And I'd like to go to the Jerome Bettis Restaurant on the North Shore one month when the Pirates aren't home.  If you can think of any other places that have outdoor seating in the vicinity of the north, let me know.

Our book for May is historical fiction novel, Circling the Sun by Paula McClain (author of The Paris Wife which was a great book).  Here's some info:

Paula McLain, author of the phenomenal bestseller The Paris Wife, now returns with her keenly anticipated new novel, transporting readers to colonial Kenya in the 1920s. Circling the Sun brings to life a fearless and captivating woman—Beryl Markham, a record-setting aviator caught up in a passionate love triangle with safari hunter Denys Finch Hatton and Karen Blixen, who as Isak Dinesen wrote the classic memoir Out of Africa.

Brought to Kenya from England as a child and then abandoned by her mother, Beryl is raised by both her father and the native Kipsigis tribe who share his estate. Her unconventional upbringing transforms Beryl into a bold young woman with a fierce love of all things wild and an inherent understanding of nature’s delicate balance. But even the wild child must grow up, and when everything Beryl knows and trusts dissolves, she is catapulted into a string of disastrous relationships.

Beryl forges her own path as a horse trainer, and her uncommon style attracts the eye of the Happy Valley set, a decadent, bohemian community of European expats who also live and love by their own set of rules. But it’s the ruggedly charismatic Denys Finch Hatton who ultimately helps Beryl navigate the uncharted territory of her own heart. The intensity of their love reveals Beryl’s truest self and her fate: to fly.

Set against the majestic landscape of early-twentieth-century Africa, McLain’s powerful tale reveals the extraordinary adventures of a woman before her time, the exhilaration of freedom and its cost, and the tenacity of the human spirit.


I look forward to seeing everyone in May!

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 PM at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Wednesday evening tennis for all levels - Cranberry

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance because you know you are attending. (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!


What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)


This event is hosted by Tammy Adkins with RAIN International and co hosted by Kobbie Alamo, Independent Consultant for Arbonne.

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Irwin area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:35 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial about yourself. Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs. Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please contact Kimberly Smith - kimfitnesschic at gmail.com

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact Debi Arnett - debadastra at yahoo.com

Any non member will be subject for removal from this site, when they RSVP that they are attend, and they are a no show.

Weekly Thursday evening rides adhering to the set time...as much as possible )) that will meander the various downtown trails & bike lanes with limited road riding as to what is only necessary.  

Starting & ending at the Riverfront Park on the Southside...accessed by 18th Street from Carson St.  Abundant (generally), free parking!  Please make every effort to be prompt or make RSVP changes so that waiting to start is kept to a minimum.  This will be greatly appreciated by all.  Some rides may have limited attendance, different hosts or other changes.  Check the site, always RSVP...& bring a positive attitude--assures a great time for all!!

Route will vary from week to week with a possible additional flair of changes of spontaneity.  As noted, estimated riding time to be 2 hours at a casual speed and with stops.  Certainly a bite can had at one of the various eateries after...but is not included time-wise in the ride so--bring a light if you're interested in doing that as we will push into the twilight hours for sure!

So...pump some air in your tires, lube the chain & let's head off for some exercise, fresh evening air...& big fun!!

results.description:
Lies, Damn Lies, and Statistics: How to Use Data Visualization to Effectively Tell the Real Story

As the world becomes more connected, the amount of data that we track and interact with is growing at an astonishing rate. Visual representations of our data are ubiquitous, and easily shared with five hundred of our closest friends, by simply clicking a button. However, how can we be sure that our data is conveying the idea we intend?

Following the six principles put forth by Information Design demigod Edward Tufte, the attendee will learn the foundations of an effective data visualization. During this talk, we will analyze both effective examples, as well as laughably poor ones.

Samantha Misurda is a member of the Advanced Data Analytics team, at the Software Engineering Institute. In a former life, she worked as a front-end web developer, and a user experience designer. Her interests lie in the areas of data visualization, distance running, and brownies -- bonus points if all three are involved simultaneously.
results.how_to_find_us: SEI cafeteria and SEI Auditorium

results.description:
How is your relationship with money? Money is like any other partnership – if it’s ignored, or we don’t feel like a worthy partner, the relationship can become toxic.

For May’s Meetup, Mastermind member Maripat Abbott will share highlights from Barbara Stanny’s book, Overcoming Underearning®: A 5 Step Plan to A Richer Life.  When Maripat left the corporate world to pursue certification in life coaching and yoga in 2004, she enrolled in Stanny’s Overcoming Underearning® tele-seminar and was so transformed, she became trained to teach the program, and has helped over 200 women create more wealth. 

In the meeting, portions of the Overcoming Underearning® tele-seminar will be highlighted so that you can take actions to earn what you are worth.  You’ll experience:

* The 5-step process that's been proven to increase income

* A unique quiz that will help identify underearning* traits

* Thought provoking journal questions that will allow you to explore blocks around money

WHAT EXACTLY IS AN UNDEREARNER?

Barbara Stanny’s definition of an “underearner” is anyone who makes less than she needs or desires, despite efforts to do otherwise. Overcoming Underearning has nothing to do with the amount of money you make.  You can earn over 6 figures and STILL have an unhealthy relationship with money.

Just a reminder that this group is different from other women's groups that are primarily geared towards networking. We exchange business cards in order to keep in touch, but this is not a venue for recruiting customers or clients. Thank you for respecting the purpose of this specific group. 

Visitors are welcome! We are a friendly and supportive group and look forward to meeting you. After your first visit to a Friday meeting if you feel that this group is a good fit for you, I invite you to continue with us and become a paid member at the low cost of $55 annually. results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."

results.description:
Hello Western PA Gamers!


Looks like we found another venue for the Western PA gaming meetups!  

A new attendance record for one of our events saw 26 gamers enjoying the April 22nd event.  With that kind of turnout I think we are going to look at having bi-weekly events here at the Market District in Settler's Ridge.    

The venue has a nice variety of hot food, snacks, Starbucks, beer, wine, and is open 24 hours!  

It is first come first serve on the seating but as members begin arriving at 5:00 we can throw some games on the larger tables to reserve them.  The venue probably has over twenty tables and the room can comfortably hold over 60 people.  It gets a little crowded at dinner time but thins out after 7:00 or so and is pretty much empty after 9:00.  


This is a great centrally located spot where our Airport area players can get to quickly as well as the Northern and City players. This location is probably only 15-20 minutes from the Fort Pitt tunnel.  

A little about what we play...

Today's board games come in all different shapes, sizes, themes, components, and our group plays all kinds.. Here are some examples of the types of games we play... 


Party games like:  Codenames, Spyfall, and Dixit.

Euro style games like:  Five Tribes, Orleans, Puerto Rico, Viticulture, and Lords of Waterdeep.

Cooperative games like:  Pandemic, Flash Point, and Dead of Winter.

Abstract games like:  Qwirkle, Blokus, and Hive.

Card games like:  Dominion, Glory to Rome, Diamonds and Muchkin.

Those are just a few of the games that can be seen being played at our meetups every week.

Our members come in all shapes and sizes and span from young to older but all seem to have a great time when we get together!

Our organizers try to be very accommodating to new players and try to pick games appropriate to your skill level and that we think you would enjoy.  Our goal is to get you enthusiastic about the hobby.

If there is a game that you would like to try out just r.s.v.p. to one of our meetups and suggest it down in the chat.  Chances are that one of us has it in our collection and we can bring it out.

Look forward to introducing the hobby to many more players in 2016 and continued good times with our regulars.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans. 

See you soon!

Russ.

Sunday Assembly is joining the Steel City Skeptics for a drink and good conversation.

Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, atheists, humanists, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. There is no specific topic. It is just an open discussion among fellow freethinkers about science, religion, skepticism, beer, life and leisure. Both teetotalers and those who imbibe moderately are equally welcomed. We meet the third or fourth Friday of each month, skipping August and December. We start gathering at 7 pm, but latecomers are more than welcome. Hope to see you on Friday night!

This is more about having a good time and making new friends & relationships. We typically have 35-45 in attendance, so its's always a nice- sized group for meeting & getting acquainted.
Total cost is $25 and includes everything: unlimited bowling from 7-10pm, bowling shoes, soft drinks, chicken salad, pizza, & brownies. This also includes tax/tip. It's a great deal and a perfect opportunity to get to talk to & know lots of new & interesting people. It's a very relaxed, casual, and friendly environment, which is sometimes hard to find, & it makes it so much easier to mix and mingle. We're also heading over to Squirrel Hill Sports Bar for some of the city's best karaoke after we're done bowling. They have some great Friday night drink specials too. Click "join" on the event if you can make it on the 20th. It's going be fun one! Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Meet in lobby by 7:45 pm (doors open at 7:30).  Film at 8 pm.

Harris Theater

“Monty Python by way of Tim Burton and The Princess Bride” -indieWIRE.

Before the Brothers Grimm, there was 17th-century Italian poet Giambattista Basile, who wrote equally unsettling tales of fantasy/adventure. This lavish film offers three of those ancient fairytales, intertwined and illustrated with a blazing cinematic style that makes Tim Burton seem tame. We see an over-sized flea as a pet, outdoor orgies, a king battling a sea serpent – then his queen eating the heart of the serpent for fertility. There’s much more to experience in this unforgettable, highly-imaginative fairytale for grown-ups. The international cast features John C. Riley, Salma Hayek, Toby Jones and Vincent Cassel. In English.

Matteo Garrone | Italy/UK | 2016 | 125 min

Trailer:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Afup26-_3iw

results.description:
After 10 years of Attack Theatre's wildly popular signature fundraiser The Dirty Ball, Attack Theatre unveils two new fundraising concept events for 2016 -- a very eclectic, but very upscale One Night Stand (on February 13) and The Down and Dirty Dance Party (which is expected to be somewhat more affordable and draw a larger crowd) on May 20.

Attack Theatre is an award-winning modern dance company now in its 21st season which has performed over 100 original works throughout the U.S. and various countries, in addition to a providing exceptional educational arts outreach to thousands of local students.

This one-night-only event at Spirit, a former Moose lodge turned bar and pizza joint in Lawrenceville, is for all of you who got down on the dance floor with us at The Dirty Ball over the years, making the event so special and so much fun.

Tickets are just $20 (or $15 for students/teachers/seniors/artists) https://www.showclix.com/event/the-down-and-dirty-dance-p?width=600&height=600&iframe=true Please note that this event is strictly 21+


There will be DJs spinning records all night, special Attack Theatre performances, interactivities, and a cash bar featuring cold drinks and hot pizza. This event is for the “20 somethings, retirees, starving artists and bankers,” (Pittsburgh Tribune-Review) and you. Join us at Spirit and bring your adventurous attitude to the dance floor all night long!

Check out the DJ line-up throughout the evening (and please read further below for more info about the DJs and what they spin!)

   Eye Jay the DJ from 8pm - 9:30pm
   Pandemic Pete from 9:30pm - 11pm
   DJ Bamboo from 11pm - 12:30am
   Selecta from 12:30am - 2am

For more information about The Down and Dirty Dance Party, please visit http://www.attacktheatre.com/attend/down-and-dirty-dance-party

Check out this article where The Down and Dirty Dance Party is featured among the "11 Pittsburgh events not to miss in May" as rated by NEXTPittsburgh  http://www.nextpittsburgh.com/current-features/11-pittsburgh-events-not-miss-may/2/

With the huge success of Attack Theatre's previous events, we can assume that The Down and Dirty Dance Party will also be a very edgy, eclectic evening which will attract a huge crowd for a one-night only experience of dance, music, art installations, interactive games, etc. 

So we'll update the Meetup description as more information becomes available for The Down and Dirty Dance Party  http://www.attacktheatre.com/attend/down-and-dirty-dance-party

For more information about Attack Theatre, including other upcoming performances as part of the[masked] season, please visit www.attacktheatre.com

For more information about Spirit, please visit http://www.spiritpgh.com 

About the DJs and What They Spin!

Eye Jay the DJ: young trap princess/DJ based in Pittsburgh via Jersey blending sultry R&B, hip-hop, dancehall, house, and jersey club sounds to craft her signature sound throughout the tri-state underground

Pandemic Pete: fuzes together tropical bass, cumbia, dancehall, bhangra, electro shaabi, chalga, Russian folk, bollywood, afrobeats, azonto, kuduro, Brazilian bass, Asian pop, and Balkan beats.

DJ Bamboo: Turntablism, hip-hop, house, dance/club, reggae, funk, and top 40.

Selecta: old school hip-hop/samples/funk + soul/house/reggae


Stay tuned for updates!!

results.description:
Resonance Works closes the season with Mahler's epic Song of the Earth with texts from ancient chinese poetry. These performances are an exciting collaboration with Texture Contemporary Ballet, rising stars in the world of dance. Texture's founder and co-artistic director Alan Obuzor was named one Dance Magazine's top 25 dancers to watch in 2013. Mezzo-soprano Brooke Larimer (Macbeth) makes her return to Resonance Works for this performance, alongside tenor Robert Frankenberry (Macbeth, Amahl).

This is going to be an epic program of amazing classical music from turn of the century Austria. German poetry, beautiful music---what could be better?!?! Jason Hohn will also be performing in the concert, so please feel free to say hi to him and the artists after the program!

When: May 20 at 8 pm and May 22 at 3 pm
Where: University of Pittsburgh's Charity Randall Theatre (inside the Stephen Foster Memorial)
What: Arnold Schoenberg's Verklärte Nacht and Gustav Mahler's Das Lied von Der Erde

Tickets are available at https://www.artful.ly/resonance-works-pittsburgh/ Use promo code MEETUP for 50% off advance tickets! (please select General Admission or General Admission Priority Seating options)

Because regular advance General Admission tickets are normally $25, you'll save $12.50 with the MEETUP discount code for advance tickets.  FYI, other price levels include $15 student and $20 senior. And for those that wish to sit as close to the stage as possible, there is also a Priority Seating option (normally $35, but you'll save $12.50 with the MEEUP discount code) while Senior Priority seating is $30. 

Please note that when buying at the door, ticket prices are slightly higher (typically $5 more than the advance ticket price)

Meetup Considerations

When you RSVP, please indicate whether you're interested in attending on Friday May 20 or Sunday May 22.  As always, it is also OK if you prefer attending on your own with family and friends instead.

MORE ABOUT THE PROGRAM

Resonance Works closes its third season with Mahler's epic Das Lied von der Erde in the Schoenberg/Riehn version for chamber orchestra. Described by Leonard Bernstein as Mahler’s “greatest symphony,” this song cycle for two soloists and orchestra sets seven of the texts from Hans Bethge's Die chinesische Flöte, a volume of ancient Chinese poetry rendered into German. Opening the program will be Schoenberg’s own Verklärte Nacht in the original version for string sextet. Inspired by Richard Dehmel’s poem of the same name and his strong feelings upon meeting his future wife, Verklärte Nacht is regarded as Schoenberg's earliest important work. These performances are an exciting collaboration with Texture Contemporary Ballet, rising stars in the world of dance. Texture's founder and co-artistic director Alan Obuzor was named one of Dance Magazine's top 25 dancers to watch in 2013. Brooke Larimer, mezzo-soprano makes her return to Resonance Works for these performances, alongside tenor Robert Frankenberry.

MORE ABOUT RESONANCE WORKS | PITTSBURGH

For over a century, Pittsburgh’s reinvention and revitalization has been fueled by a commitment to innovation, excellence, and hard work. These standards and values are as critical to Resonance Works as they are to the industries that are fundamental to the region’s identity.

Art, people, and place resonate together to create memorable experiences.

Artist-driven programming sets Resonance Works apart. Our artists are creative partners in every way: performers, administrators, board members, volunteers, and donors. Whether we perform in coffee shops, warehouses, or concert halls, we create unique experiences for audiences and artists alike.

Art resonates throughout Pittsburgh.
Resonance Works embraces all of Pittsburgh. By the end of the[masked] season we will have performed on the North Side, in Shadyside, Downtown, Regent Square, Oakland, and the Strip District. Auspicious beginnings.
Resonance Works launched in 2013 with two ambitious and contrasting projects: a fully-staged production of Verdi’s MACBETH, and our first “sono-mosaic” project entitled Natural Frequency; we worked with over 80 artists, and our projects were funded exclusively by 70 individual donors. Will you help us build upon this foundation?

Why be excited about Resonance Works?
Unique. Artist-driven. Forged in Pittsburgh. Transform your excitement by bridging your passion with ours.

results.description:
</a> <a href="http://wpwbikeclub.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/SpringRideBanner1a.png">

Welcome to the 1st Annual Spring Ride & Picnic! The Western Pennsylvania Wheelmen welcome members and their family and friends to join us for rides, food, and fun. Enjoy the quiet country roads of Butler County.


Each loop of this 3-loop event starts and ends at Adam’s Township Community Park giving riders the opportunity to refuel before rolling out on their next loop. Enjoy snacks, cookies, and beverages all day.


Lunch will be served too! Bring your friends to join and support the club.

Event Information
REGISTRATION: 8:00 am to 10 am ~ All riders
must roll out by 10:30 am
COST: Free to WPW Bike Club members.
Non-members: $20/Individual or $30/Family (includes
1-year WPW membership)
LOCATION: Adam’s Township Community Park,
“Township Shelter”, located at 698 Valencia Road,
Mars, PA 16046
ROUTES: Enjoy 3 loops offering a combination of
13/25/38/50/63 miles. Both the BLUE route (25.4
miles) and the GREEN route (25.8 miles) offer beautiful
scenery through the countryside of Butler County, 30-
minutes north of Pittsburgh. HINT: The BLUE route is
a little more challenging than the GREEN route. The
RED route offers a quick 13-miles through Mars, PA
and the surrounding countryside to complete a metric
century.
MAPS & CUE SHEETS: Get turn-by-turn navigation
with the FREE RidewithGPS app on your smartphone
when you access the WPW’s Club Account. Print your
cue sheets or make the route available offline and you’ll
be on your way.
SAG WAGONS: Provided along the routes between
8:00 am and 3:00 pm. Riders are expected to be able
to make their own minor repairs, including flat tires.
FOOD WILL BE SERVED! Energy bars, fruit,
coffee, and other beverages will be available all day. At
the end of each loop, you’ll have the opportunity to
refuel. Lunch will be served from 12:00 pm to 2:30 pm.
~ Helmets are required on all WPW Bike Club rides. ~

Ride flyer:

http://wpwbikeclub.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Spring-Ride-Picnic-Flyer.pdf

At this breakfast, Jeff Leake, Pastor of Allison Park Church, will be sharing what he believes to be the most important leadership lesson for the next generation. 


Jeff's Bio:

Jeff Leake has served as the Lead Pastor of Allison Park Church, in the North Hills of Pittsburgh, PA, for over twenty years.  Jeff earned a BA in Bible from Central Bible College and an MA in Missiology from the Assemblies of God Theological Seminary.  

Melodie Leake earned an A.A. in Bible from Central Bible College.  She serves as the Women's Pastor at APC.  Jeff and Melodie  have been married for over 25 years.  Together they have five children (four boys and one girl).

Most notably, Jeff has been instrumental in helping many new churches to get started. In 1996, APC began planting churches under Jeff's leadership.   Currently, there have been over 17 churches planted (over 10 in the Pittsburgh area).

Jeff founded the Reach Northeast Network to train and mentor the new church planting pastors in the network.  ReachNortheast.com

results.description:
It's time, my friends! Let's get together and pass around those fabulous styles just sitting in the back of our wardrobes waiting to be loved!

This event will be held at my home and there will be snacks and drinks available, but you're welcome to bring a bag of chips or bottle of wine to share! Alcoholic and non-alcoholic options will be available, as will vegetarian options for appetizers. For the swap itself, please bring any good-quality clothes you want to send out into the world! You'll be welcome to take from the supplies that are provided by our fellow members and anything that doesn't get claimed will be donated to a local women's shelter (if anyone has one in mind, please send me a message! My plan is to just google one if there are no suggestions!) As always, all genders are welcome to attend and enjoy, and if you have men's fashion, please feel welcome to bring that as well!

Please bring hangers for your clothes! I will try to provide a rack or two to hang things up so we don't have massive, disorganized piles, but this simple thing will help a great deal!

There will be space available for you to try clothes on privately. My home is in Southside, so please plan ahead to find convenient parking. Most of the areas around my home have two-hour permit parking and we don't want any tickets happening!

I'm happy to answer any questions, and a huge thank you and shout-out to Molly and Bethany for helping to facilitate this exciting event. :)

Please let your friends and family know about this event! The more donations and people we have, the more fun this will be!

I would like this to be mainly focused on clothing in larger sizes, however, so I'm going to draw a soft limit at a size 12 minimum for donations.

results.description:
THIS IS AN ONGOING GROUP. The topic for May's meetup is "The Power of Hands on Healing". We will discuss the spiritual and scientific aspects of hands on healing, including Reiki. I just got certified in my Reiki Master Teacher certification and will be doing free exchange of healing's for those who ask. As I get new topic interest, we will move to those as well. The history of contact healing will also be presented. Others who join us are welcome to practice, or offer, their own healing modality as well.

This group is new, and is forming as the group grows. We will cover ongoing topics of metaphysics, and really anything that could be regarded as existing outside of objective reality, and seeks to investigate the nature of reality. Big words, but true. Simply put, the groups' questioning and desires to know the things that are hard to explain will define what each new topic is each month. So, as the group grows so do the topics.

This group is democratic where everyone is encouraged to join in the conversation, anyone can bring a gift to share--be it intuition, Reiki, dream work and lucid dreaming, numerology, astrology, Ascension, Enlightenment, meditation, visualization, channeling, archetypes, Angels, manifestation, Indigo Children and all of the other New Age children, Tarot, Shamanism, synchronicity, power animals and objects, multi-dimensional awareness, the 3rd, 4th, and 5th dimensions, the collective unconscious and collective conscious, spirit art, spirit guides, sacred space, empaths, medical intuition, past lives and I am sure much much more.

We decide as a group what we want to study and share. This is an open group, anyone can attend. The purpose is for spiritual, emotional and soul growth. This group is also a support group of sorts, as we grow more aware it can sometimes be a little scary. So, we are there for each other--we all have our own unique experiences to share and teach. At times we can bring in teaching guests to learn from.

The group is not only a forum and place where we can discuss and learn about metaphysics, but is also a place where each group member can share their experiences of this much shifting world where more and more people are feeling some sort of spiritual shift happening all around!

The first meeting will be a get together to decide what we want to study, and to get to know everyone. Every group meetup will begin with a meditation after introductions. Every group meeting will have a well wishing time at the end, as everyone share a message from their intuitive mind.

Most people wanted to meet on a weekend, so I chose the third Saturday of every month.

I was thinking about meeting at the Panera Bread Company on Center avenue in Oakland, they have a private meeting room I can set up for our group.

results.name: The Metaphysical Meetup Group

The Venture Outdoors Festival is held at Point State Park. The Park is located right in downtown Pittsburgh. Find directions to downtown here.

results.description:
**We may have to tweak the route a bit to stay on the paved areas of the trail & the very lightly traveled streets to do our ride.  Weather forecast (last I heard) was still a bit iffy for rain [showers].  I'll check it in the early a.m. & post any other 'adjustments'.

Let's see if this is a go this Sunday!  We'll do a 33.5 mile (total) ride from the Riverfront Park off of Carson St along the Great Allegheny Passage to...or almost to Little Boston whichever is 16.75 miles. We will be stopping for the needed or wanted 'eats' in the Waterfront on the return.  Why 33.5 miles?  Well, if done 10 times--your in DC(!)...at least according to the GAP mileage chart.  Even the weather will change from the start to the end, so be somewhat versatile with your clothing choice along with the other accouterments that you...or your bike may need.  Questions?  Post or message me directly.  

So let's start with this & see how far we can extend it on future rides.  We'll stay together (or stop as necessary to gather) until at least the Pump House where we may stretch out as you would on the way to DC until the turnaround mileage point where we will hang to select a restaurant.  Rated as just above a beginner ride, only because of the length, but still most doable by almost everyone with the proper mindset. )

Please...'yes' RSVP's only, save the 'No('s) for changes only. Thanks!

Keep cranking the pedals...doin' the miles, turning the wheels & making the smiles!

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 10:30 AM at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more. 
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels. 
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
***Note that this is not our regular location -- it's across the street, downhill, in Margaret Morrison Hall Room 119.*** 
CATS Dance hosts monthly contra dances at Carnegie Mellon University. Everyone is welcome, regardless of age, race, gender, or ability. We have a different band and caller each month.

No experience is necessary, but you can show up 15 minutes early if you'd like a mini-lesson from our veteran volunteers. 

Please help us pay for the band -- we suggest $10, but give whatever you're able to. We also welcome folks who'd like to help set up early (starting at 4:45pm) or pack up after the dance. Also - contra dancing is hungry business - if you like, please bring a snack to share at the break.

---

In May, we've got a bunch of lovely guests from West Virginia -- Rachel Eddy calling to the Contrarians!

Here's the Contrarians in action:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mSYKXBpQLpc

The Contrarians deliver hot contradance music from West Virginia, where the traditions trend toward square dance and bluegrass. The Contrarians, however, as their name implies, are not restricted by genres: Celtic, French Canadian, Swing, Gypsy, as well as Appalachian and original tunes are woven together and spiced with Afro-pop, Reggae, blues, and other grooves. 

The Contrarians are:
Will Carter: stick bass Paul Epstein: fiddle, foot percussionJohn Longwell: mandolin, saxophone, tenor banjo, fiddleAndy Park: acoustic and electric guitars. http://www.contrarianswv.com/

Rachel Eddy is perhaps best known for her fiddle, banjo and guitar stylings, but she's branching out into calling and we can't wait to hear her smiling voice guiding us through the dances. https://www.facebook.com/Rachel-Eddy-WV-fiddler-244874467371/

---

Please note that most of our community is not using Meetup.com. Though it may look like nobody is attending, rest assured that there will be lots of people at the dance! You can find us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/catsdancepgh/events!

results.description:
This event is hosted by Embody Healing, LLC and presented by Rebekah Gamble, Holistic Practitioner. Here are the details: Well, you've asked for it and here it is!
I run a holistic company based on energy practices (and a few other things), and I've run several other successful businesses as well as non-profits. Every single venture has been wildly successful. I get a lot of questions about how what and why I do things. People want to know best practices, how to do different things, and how to actually be successful. My husband was actually pushing me to do a weekend retreat to teach you everything I know, but in all reality, I think we could probably do better just by answering questions you have and sharing time. I have carved two hours out of my schedule, and I will answer any business related questions you have to the best of my ability, tell you when I don't know the answer and where to get it, and give you resources for where you can get help.

I don't give legal or financial advice, and this should not be taken as such, but I am a certified career and professional coach, and this event definitely falls into that category. If it's successful or overly successful, maybe we'll do more than one. Please also keep in mind that I am in PA, and everything I know is geared towards the PA regulations and such. Because I DO NOT give legal or financial advice, you will need to check with state laws.

We will start by my answering these questions, which I feel I get most often, and then it will be open questions from then on out:

-What do I need to do to legally practice energy work and what are my limits (hint- being a reverend or minister does NOT legally protect you)? What's the differences between being certified and being licensed?

-How do I start a business and what's the difference between an LLC, Scorp and 501(c)?

-What sort of requirements are there for me to practice counseling, coaching, energy work, massague, etc? Can I teach whatever I want if I'm certified in the practice?

-Why aren't all ceremonies and spiritual work legal, and what's the difference between state and federal legalities?

-How do I publish a book and should I do it on my own or go with a publishing house?

-How do I promote myself and advertise?

-How do I survive the FDA, IRS and other regulations while still being able to talk about my business?

-How do I price my services?

We're also going to take a look at some of my best tips for actually running and being successful with a business. The fact is, business advice from the rest of the business world is often opposite of what you need to know to run a holistic business, so let's look at some of that, why that is, and best practices for creating a thriving practice.

This will be like my other online calls. I will need you to pre-pay by sending a payment or email requesting an invoice to [masked]. I will set everything up, and we will get through as many of your questions as we can in the two hours. The cost for the Ask Anything is $30.

Have a great day and hope to see you there!
results.name: Ask Anything: Running a Holistic Business

results.description: Join us at Wind in the Willows Acupuncture for Restorative Yoga. Restorative yoga practice is designed to restore the nervous system and help release deeply held tensions from the body and mind. As a result of a restorative practice, the nervous system will send and receive fewer messages, triggering the parasympathetic nervous system which is responsible for balancing the body. Deep restorative work improves range of motion and joint mobility, reduces pain and the effects of stress. We use props such as blocks, blankets and straps to support the postures, while gently stretching and strengthening the body. This class is appropriate for students of all ages, shapes and experience levels.

results.description:
Mac vs. PC vs. Linux vs. iOS vs. Android
     By Dave Sevick

We live in rapidly changing world where competing computer platforms are not as important anymore. The old hardware battles of Mac vs. PC have taken a backstage to software challenges among office suites, browsers, engineering and design apps that are generally available by download immediately. We’ll compare 5 major development platforms used today: Mac vs. PC vs. Linux vs. iOS vs. Android … showing common ground on core productivity apps used worldwide. Interesting conversation for sure! And this software discussion is at the center of all outreach missions we serve around the world. We are moving toward a more level playing field with many productivity apps free to the public.

Dave Sevick, Computer Reach Founder, Apple Consultant
Dave remains an Apple computer consultant in his 26th year serving Western PA, WV, OH, MD. In addition to serving Apple clients in homes, schools and business, Dave formed the North Pittsburgh Macintosh Users Group in 1996. That organization spawned the Mac Missionaries volunteer-based recycling effort, later expanding operations in 2010 to create Computer Reach, a 501c3 designated public charity. In 2012 Dave expanded Computer Reach beyond Apple refurbishing to include PCs running Linux and mobile devices.

Cost: No charge. Buy your own drinks and dinner. (The menu is varied and the food is very good at the BBT).

5:30 pm. Social networking (get get here as early as 5 pm)
6:00 pm Dinner (Order from menu)
Followed by presentation and Q&A

results.description:
The Faith Club

Editorial ReviewsFrom Publishers WeeklyIn the wake of 9/11, Idliby, an American Muslim of Palestinian descent, sought out fellow mothers of the Jewish and Christian faiths to write a children's book on the commonalities among their respective traditions. In their first meeting, however, the women realized they would have to address their differences first. Oliver, an Episcopalian who was raised Catholic, irked Warner, a Jewish woman and children's author, with her description of the Crucifixion story, which sounded too much like "Jews killed Jesus" for Warner's taste. Idliby's efforts to join in on the usual "Judeo-Christian" debate tap into a sense of alienation she already feels in the larger Muslim community, where she is unable to find a progressive mosque that reflects her non–veil-wearing, spiritual Islam. The ladies come to call their group a "faith club" and, over time, midwife each other into stronger belief in their own respective religions. More Fight Club than book club, the coauthors pull no punches; their outstanding honesty makes for a page-turning read, rare for a religion nonfiction book. From Idliby's graphic defense of the Palestinian cause, Oliver's vacillations between faith and doubt, and Warner's struggles to acknowledge God's existence, almost every taboo topic is explored on this engaging spiritual ride. 


(Oct. 3)


Copyright © Reed Business Information, a division of Reed Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.From 

Booklist

 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2016 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.

results.description:
See Playlist Below. The South Hills Ukulele group has been playing together for a year now and has progressed to playing songs with up to 5-8 chords.  If you're a beginner player and know the basic chords, please join us.  You might not be able to play all the songs right away but as you progress, you'll find you can play most of the songs.  We're all still learning.  If you play an instrument other than the ukulele, please bring that as well.  We're finding that other instruments add variety to our music and we're allowing instrumental breaks between verses where you can "break out" and show case your special musical talent.   We meet at Mt. Lebanon Library the 2nd and 4th Tuesday of each month.

If you're rather new to the ukulele and want to pick up some tips, please come at 6:30 PM for quick lessons in strumming, note reading, fingerpicking, etc.  

The group will choose the songs they want to play using "The Daily Ukulele 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is available from local music stores and online.

results.description:
In the past three meet ups we’ve talked about the many types of spirit guides that are available to us, in our next meet up we will have a fun and interactive session on how to work with them.

The greatest obstacle to receiving wisdom from them on a regular basis is simply being misinformed about who they’re supposed to communicate with us. We will talk about the subtlety of the spirit guides how to recognize and not dismiss their signs.

Once you’ve invited them to assist you, they’ll seize each moment and use every means possible to get your attention. We’ll have some fun exercises on how to recognize their efforts and appreciate how close and committed to communicating with us they are.

We’ll talk about how guides work with messengers, how they speak to us, and how to learn the names of our spirit guides.

Look forward to seeing you at our next meet up!

Blessings,

Joe
results.name: Six Sensory Living

results.description: Lovie comes from an old New England family who has lost most of its money and she is forced to attend her elite boarding school on scholarship and skip college to go to work in New York's world of high fashion. She never loses touch with her friends from boarding school and her longstanding friendships with two of them, Dinah and Avis, are a major focus of the novel.  The book is Gutcheon's portrait of upper class Manhattan life from roughly 1960 to sometime near the present.  It is a story told with intelligence that touches on some intriguing themes in regards to friendship, confidences, gossip and cruelty.

results.description: Liber Pyramidos is one of the most recently published and least frequently performed of the "canon" of Thelemic rituals left to us by Aleister Crowley. One reason for this is that the ritual as published is frustratingly incomplete in terms of rubrication - it gives the words to be spoken and even images to be visualized, but not an explicit description of what actions the magician is to perform. This lecture will give background history about the ritual, a structural breakdown of its parts, speculative theory about its purpose and function for the Thelemic magician, a proposed rubric for performance, and an exemplification of the ritual itself.
results.name: Liber Pyramidos Lecture by Ron Labhart

results.description:
Note: To see the full course outline, please click here!
We are proud to announce the launch of our Spring 2016 Inner Strength Training Boot Camp!

We will be kicking things off with relaxed and casual open house event on the 24th. There are 2 primary purposes for this meeting: 1) to share information about the program and discuss how we've developed it over the past year, and 2) get your critical feedback on how we can make an already great program even better!

Come hungry! Food and drink will be provided compliments of Pizza Parma downtown. The event will only last around an hour, so be sure to arrive on time. 

This event is free and open to all men who have made their personal growth a priority in their lives. We want to connect directly with you and hear first hand what changes you want to make in your life most.

Our two-month Boot Camp ($75/mo) provides training in areas such as: naming and processing emotions, responding instead of reacting, creating space, practicing mindfulness, building healthy relationships, and many more. It is a powerful, high-tempo program for those who truly want to create a "new normal" of growth.


Want to learn more and discover how you can help us develop the inner strength of today's men? RSVP now and join us on the 24th!

Looking forward to seeing you there,

- J Stamatelos

results.description: When Felicia Day was a girl, all she wanted was to connect with other kids. Growing up in the Deep South, where she was “home-schooled for hippie reasons,” she looked online for companionship, becoming an early adopter of the internet and finding joy and unlikely friendships in the emerging digital world.  Her “relentlessly funny and surprisingly inspirational” memoir chronicles her progress from weird kid to online entertainment pioneer (The Guild, Dragon Age), actress (Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Eureka, Supernatural, Dr. Horrible), and acknowledged “queen of the geeks”, embracing her weirdness to find her place in the world.

We missed those of you who couldn't make it to the April ROKI Roundtable, but I hope you can make it in May! This month's theme is an incredibly important one - Vulnerability. Being vulnerable and asking for the help you need is such an important topic to discuss, especially for professional mothers who are juggling so much responsibility day to day. I'm excited to announce that the May Meetup will also include a Panel Expert on the subject - Jess Strong! Jess has a Masters in Public Policy from CMU and has years of experience working with non-profits in the fields of mental health and social work. Jess is also the visionary creator behind The Whetstone Workgroup - a new co-working space in the East End featuring drop-in daycare! This class will be an interesting and very educational discussion about what exactly Lyme disease is, how to prevent it, what to do if contracted, and how to manage it if it is already established.

I will discuss proper protocols and herbal regimens that can help in the prevention or in the management of chronic Lyme.

I'll talk a lot about Stephen Buhner's work in the Lyme community and will have his books in class for you to leaf through.

With the presence of Lyme seemingly on the rise in this area, I hope this class will bring a deeper understanding of what it is and hopefully help to give you confidence with your health!

More in-depth Lyme discussions/ workshops throughout the Summer, stay tuned!

Advanced Beginners Skate (6:30pm) for those who can brake and skate with confidence and are ready to improve their skills. Ability to skate small hills and some street traffic. Helmets and wrist guards required as a minimum on all skates.

Occasional post skate tailgate social gathering or walk to local eateries after the skate usually around 8:00 pm.

Note: All skates are weather permitting. If the streets are dry we should be skating!

Lessons are conducted by the National Skate Patrol.

results.description:
Hi everybody!

At this month's VPU meeting, in addition to our usual federal, state, and local updates, we will begin a regular monthly segment on being prepared.  Now preparedness means different things to different people, and while some folks might be prepared for a total electrical grid shutdown, we think it is at least prudent to be prepared for an unexpected winter storm, flood, or some other natural disaster, or possibly a Flint, Michigan, water situation.  It's worth thinking about and worth talking about, so we will start the conversation and begin to share ideas at this month's meeting.

In addition to that, Bob Howard will lead a discussion on Opportunity -- not just opportunity for the politically connected and those businesses with enough lobbyists to overcome the half million pages of federal regulations and the 78,000 page IRS tax code -- but opportunity for EVERYBODY!  We must work to end the special privileges for some and work toward achieving equal justice and equal opportunities for ALL!  We'll get that conversation started at this month's meeting.

We'll also be discussing VPU's Second Annual Blue Lives Matter Rally in support of local police, which is currently scheduled for Saturday, June 18, 2016 (meetup to be posted soon) in Moon Township, PA (rain day will be Saturday, June 25, 2016).

And last but not least, we'll be discussing VPU's summer picnic, which will be held Saturday, July 30, 2016 in Moon Park at the Clearview pavilion (times will be decided and the meetup for the picnic will also be posted soon).

So come on out for some interesting conversations this month with like-minded friends!  I hope to see you all there!
results.name: VPU's Monthly Meeting for May 2016 (Preparedness and Opportunity)

results.description:
Welcome to CFI's monthly lecture night series!

Sue Frietsche is a Senior Staff Attorney at the Women's Law Project in Pittsburgh and is also an adjunct law professor at the University of Pittsburgh. She teaches a course titled Reproduction, Sexuality, and the Law. As an attorney at the Women's Law Project, she has litigated on behalf of low-income women, domestic violence survivors, reproductive health care providers and their patients, teenage women needing confidential abortions, custodial parents owed child support, lesbian and gay parents, incarcerated women, and pregnant women excluded from substance abuse treatment.

Her talk tonight will be focused on the book Living in the Crosshairs, The Untold Stories of Anti-Abortion Terrorism by David Cohen and Krysten Connon. As an attorney on the front lines of the social conservatives all out assault and, at times, violent war on reproductive freedom and rights, Sue is infinitely familiar with the dangers faced by anyone courageous enough to provide reproductive health services. Fortunately, we have chairs so that you can be sitting down as you learn about some of the egregious wrongs perpetrated against people committed to helping women in crisis – and sometimes against the women themselves.

If you have speaker suggestions and/or ideas that are in keeping with our mission, please feel free to email your suggestions to [masked]
See you there!

P.S. We usually head to Ali Baba's on nearby Craig Street between 5:00 and 5:30 p.m. for a pre-lecture dinner. Please leave a comment below if you are coming to dinner so we can include you in the reservation. Thanks!

To learn about all the secular groups in Pittsburgh, visit the Pittsburgh Coalition of Reason website...and you can follow Pittsburgh Secular Freethinkers and CFI on Facebook!

*CFI-Pittsburgh strives to be an ADA compliant organization. Please email [masked] to request accommodations.
results.name: A Lecture With CFI

Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 PM at the tennis court of Cranberry Community park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If you are a member on the waiting list, please don't come until there is cancellation and you moved in to the RSVP list of the event. 
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Wednesday evening tennis for all levels - Cranberry

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance because you know you are attending. (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!


What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.
results.how_to_find_us: Check in with monitor

results.description:
Even if you have never tweeted or twittered on your phone (I have not, I confess...), join us for this session that is "for the birds".  Zentangle Inspired Art (ZIA) uses the our usual pattern drawing techniques.   I'll show you an embarrassingly easy-to-draw 3-stroke bird.  Draw your own, or use the pre-strung bird tiles I'll provide, including baby bird, hummingbird, flying bird, and groups of birds together.  Bring your usual tools.  I'll have tiles for you to use, but if you think you might want to work larger than the standard 3.5" tile--bring a larger paper to work on (maybe you want a whole flock or tree-full!).

Naomi, just back from a weekend with Maria and Rick, Zentangle founders, may give us a review of her experiences.  We'll give her the option to briefly report---or, if she's so enthused she may take over the whole session (in which case we'll postpone the birds until next time).  I'm looking forward to her report, but suspect she may want a bit more time to "process" her experiences for us. 

Whichever way we go, prepare to be flexible --a good time is guaranteed!

Beginners are always welcome.  (Beginners do not need to bring supplies; and will receive advice on buying supplies they may want to purchase locally or online.)

Group, meet-up membership and instruction are free; donations to defray costs, however are welcomed.

Generally Sue Schneider, organizer, brings all supplies needed for projects/instruction.  (Additional supplies you may want to use at home are available for purchase.  If you have a specific request for official Zentangle products, kits, or tools, Sue will be happy to order them for you and deliver at the meet-up--you won't have to pay shipping costs!)

If you are a regular attender, simply bring your usual kit of supplies, and any other materials that may be specified for the particular session.

Fun, inspiration and good company are guaranteed!!
results.name: Birds of a feather: Mt. Lebanon Zentanglers
